editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: TO THE ILLVSTRIOVS PRINCESS, MARY Dutcheſs of RICHMOND and LENOX.
div.p:
I Humbly offer Your Grace the laſt ſacrifice of this nature that is in my power, having only a hope that it may be receiv'd by You with that favour as when it was formerly preſented. And ſo, Madam, I only dare to appear in an addreſs to You, as others to their Altars, who by ſacrifices get pardon for their defects, if not advance their devotions. This was to your Sex indeed
a peculiar offering, whilſt all either gave as much Paſſion to their Adorers, or wiſht their Beauties great enough to do it: your Graces excellencies alone have been by all admirers eſteem'd at ſo great and juſt a value, as to create, and not reward mens paſſions. This with as juſt a reverence I preſent to you, hoping for this Romantique paſſion ſuch an entertainment as none durſt expect for real ones; your ſeverity would deny a reception to thoſe, which your charity may grant to this: And believe, he that attempts all ways to expreſs his reſpects and duty, has more then Fortune will give him leave to ſhew, The unhappy condition at this time of

closer.signed: The most humble of all your Graces moſt obliged Servants, ALEX. GOUGHE.

div.head: THE Names and Characters of the Perſons.

list.item:
Stremon
Three Lords diſaffected to th •
Prince Agenor.

Clindor, a Captain
Friends to Agenor.

Two other Princes
Suitors to Auſtell • .

div.head: Act. 1. Scaen. 1.
div.stage: Enter Lucidor, and Clindor, and a Captain, (ſeverally.)

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.p: WEll met, Clindor.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.p: I would it were ſo.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.p: Why, what miſfortune is happened, man?

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.p:
A pox on Fortune, ſhe ne'r was friend of mine; And now the wars are at end, there's no way left For men of merit to ſupply themſelves: But cou'd I
Catch that Beldam by the foretop, I would ſo Lug her Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Thou miſtakeſt,
And threatneſt Opportunity: 'tis ſhe that hath
A lock before, and bald behind; but Fortune is a •
Mighty Goddeſs, and muſt be reverenc'd.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l:
A Quean, a Strumpet by this hand; and ſh •
you talk of
Is her Bawd; they pickt my pockets with a pair o •
Dice, giving the mony to a Sot, that ſcarce knew
How to tell it when he had won it.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: That was ill luck.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: To loſe a months pay in a night, now when I' •
Never like to ſee another muſter, nor hope of booty • loſ •
O I could eat theſe fingers!

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Loſe not thy patience, and then thy monie •
Will not afflict thee.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l:
Pray will ye lend me 20 Crowns, and keep i •
for me.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Keep what?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: My patience.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Thou haſt none.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: To what end then was your grave advice,
My great Fooloſopher! ſtand by.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Believe me, if the inſolencie of theſe Commanders
That are come back with the Prince be not reſtrain'd,
This Court, beſt ordered in the world,
Will grow to Barbariſm and ſhame our Nation,
Chiefly us that ſhould keep all in form.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: My Lord, take heed whilſt you too much ſtudy
A regularity, you not forget the proper time:
The Court is yet a kind of Camp, a place of free acceſs,
In which the Prince is as the Sun,
Whoſe cheerful rays give life to all.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Wil't pleaſe your Lordſhip to buy a Virtue of me?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Sure I believe 'tis a very beggerly one.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Your Lordſhip's a witch; 'tis Patience indeed,
The beggers virtue; you ſhall have it for 20 crowns.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Sirra, this ſawcineſs may in time
Procure you the beggers puniſhment
To exerciſe your virtue, A whip.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Hum, a whip!

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Your Lordſhips reply was by much too harſh
For harmleſs merriment, and argues you
Of a proud dogged nature.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Pray teach not me to ſpeak, my Lord,
Until I go about to teach you how to fight.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I would your formal Lordſhip wore a ſword,
I ſhould moſt gladly learn.

sp.speaker: Sen:
sp.l: I do not want when I intend to wear one.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Certain you do, pray put it on againſt
I ſee you next, let this remember you.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: What inſolence is this?

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: My Lord fight with him, or by this hand
Ye have got my patience, and you ſhall pay me for't.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: How now you baſe Raſcal!

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Who's that he calls ſo?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: One ſir, that I have ſeen do bravely in the wars.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: The attribute was very courſe:
Sir, you muſt know thoſe whom I call fellows
• n arms, and who for you and me, and all
Have ſpent their bloods, muſt meet with better
Recompence then contumelious words.
'Tis ſuch as you that buz into my Fathers ears
A thouſands tales, contract his bounties into nothings •
Or little to any ſoldier; and this not as good husbands
For your maſter, but your ſelves, that your ſhares
May be greater.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: I hope your Highneſs will on better knowledg •
Change this hard opinion.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I dare engage my ſelf, your Highneſs
May abſolutely diſpoſe my Lord.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Since you eſteem him as a friend, I ſhould not
Be diſpleaſed to have cauſe to believe it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: The occaſion is only wanting, Sir.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Well my Lord, if it prove ſo, I know how
To reward thoſe that ſerve me. Go Lucidor
And enquire if my Father be ready yet.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: If it pleaſe your Majeſty, I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: You forget, my Lord,
That title is only due to my Father.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: To whom he had ſo great a mind to make complaint,
That he forgot himſelf.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Let him complain: Thoſe that are mine I will ſecure.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Who are not ſuch, deſerve not your protection.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: There, ſhare that purſe betwixt you; I'l go.
Be to night at my chamber at 9 a clock: now leave us.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: The Gods bleſs your Highneſs.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: What ſay you now to the old Beldam, is ſhe not kind?

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: She durſt do no other.

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: Sir, as I told you, upon my knowledge
Your Father is poſſeſt with a belief
That your late victories and cuſtom of commanding
In the Army, hath made you quite forget
How to obey; and Sir, to humble you, your greateſt Captains
Do receive daily affronts:

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: My Captains! even my ſelf do feel their injuries.
My needful bounty's cenſured prodigality,
My courteſie inſinuations; and all
What I have ever learnt for good or commendable
Turn to my prejudice: Nothing, I ſee,
Can pleaſe my Father, or free me from ſuſpition,
Unleſs I prove my ſelf or baſe, or fooliſh.

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: The preſent affairs, ſir, of this Kingdom
Call for a man both wiſe and valiant:
Such I muſt ſay you are; nor is this needful truth
Thus timely urged, to be eſteemed a flattery,
Though ſpoken to your ſelf. Your father, ſir, was what you are;
But now time and infirmities have brought him
Near to what we truly might call dotage
In a meaner man. And is it reaſonable
You ſhould ſtand by an idle looker on,
Whilſt his weak or falſe Councellors and he
Make peace or war with foreign States,
Diſpoſe of government and Offices at home,
Not on the beſt deſerver, but the greateſt briber,
Or ſuch a Lords particular friend or kinſman.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Truth is, I do appear now at home of no
eſteem:
Even thoſe Princes lately made ſubject
By my ſweat and blood, no one of their Ambaſſadors
Makes any particular addreſs to me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: 'Twere madneſs if they ſhould,
The certain way to miſs their ends; no ſir,
Your younger brother Clarimant is the known
Powerful Advocate for favors from the King;
And for the Prince himſelf, and power,
Are both laid proſtrate at the feet
Of his fair Couſin the Lady Clorinda.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Does ſhe not deſerve to be obeyed?

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.l:
Doubtleſs no Virgin lives that equals he •
in merit:
And yet 'tis poſſible the Prince may have
Another end beſides her perſonal worth,
Which makes him court her.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: What end?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: You know, ſir, at leaſt muſt needs have heare
Her anceſtors have been pretenders, to this Crown,
And time hardly wears out the right of Princes.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: 'Tis true, hardly where right;
But a pretenſion not then proſperous,
Neither lives but to ſhame the undertakers memory
But were it otherwiſe in this particular,
I durſt truſt my brother, indeed in any,
For I know his love to me is firm.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis a noble confidence in you,
Nor would I ſeek to change that quiet peace
That lodges in your mind, for a worſe gueſt, ſuſpition
But if I do not freely ſpeak my fears,
I ſhall be guilty of a treaſon to my Prince
And friend. Your brother ſir, foſters ambitious hopes
And howſoe'r you ſlight Clorinda's title,
That is their chiefeſt nouriſhment.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: It is impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: If I ſhould tell you, ſome believe your fathe •
Holds what I have ſaid, is conſcious that he
Does keep the Crown by wrong, and ſo would
By a marriage ſet all ſtrait; this would exact
A greater faith then you, I know, can yet allow.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: 'Tis true, for this implies my diſinheriting
The falſhood of my brother, nay ſomething mo ••

Then this, which I may chance one day to tell yo •
freely:
But now I live curbed in my perſon,
Nay my tho • ghts pent up, when I would eaſe
My heart by uttering them.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Enlarge your ſelf each way.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Oh I muſt not

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Then I will for you. My grief to ſee my Country
Loſe the advantage of your beſt of years
For action, makes me ſpeak plain and home,
Though to the hazard of my head, if you miſlike
The councel; nor will I put you upon danger,
And not ſhare it with you?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: What is't you mean? I am confident you love me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: As I do happineſs, which is included
In your knowledge of my faith and love.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Speak then.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: In ſhort 'tis this:
Propoſe a war in Germany, raiſe a great Army▪
Live there a King, ſince here you cannot.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: My father never will conſent.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Where's that Souldier or Commander, will not obey
Your ſummons?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: To raiſe an Army, my Father not allowing it,
Were treaſon; which once proclaim'd, would ſtartle
The moſt reſolute.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Scarce a man, if you ſhould on the contrary
Make known what your intents were for your Countries
Honor and profit.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: But in the mean time ſhould they ſeiſe my perſon?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: But in the mean time ſhould you ſeiſe your
Fathers perſon, which is ſure much eaſier to do.
There's but few Nations that adore the ſetting ſun;
The braver ſpirits do attend his riſe,
And hope to mount with him aloft.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Though I confeſs I willingly would aid
My Fathers feeble arm to hold the ſcepter right,
I would not force it from his hands.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Two hands upon one ſcepter; men will interpret
Violence; however ſince 'twas ordain'd in one,
If violence at all, let it be powerful in effect:
The happy iſſue then may change the attribute
To providence care of the preſent & the future ſtate:

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: It is an affair of a high conſequence,
Pray ſee me in the morning, I muſt take time
To think—

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Do Prince, 'tis my deſire, ſince thought
Muſt make that poiſon work, I have diſtill'd
Into thy ſoul; the compounds are ſo ſtrong
And operative, that it muſt cauſe deſtruction
To thy ſelf, father, or brother, if not all.
But ſoft; much time, and many dangers
Muſt be paſt, ere I can hope to touch that happy
Period; the part I long have acted
Muſt be ſtill maintain'd; a ſeeming faithful
Servant to the father and his ſons,
By each believ'd ſo tender of their ſafeties
And their honour, as if I had no ſenſe
Of what concern'd the other two.
The grounds thus laid, and mutual jealouſies growing
In each, I am ſecured from a diſcovery
By any general conference of theirs:
Nay, ſhould an intimacie hold, as 'tis not like,
Betwixt the brothers, yet am I ſtill ſecure
By their own nobleneſs, ſcorning to tell Councels
The ſecrets of an Enemy, much leſs reveal theſe of a friend,
Which when I do, I ſhal no other but my ſelf betray;
Friendſhip's an uſeful word, the ſubſtance thrown away.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Nay, Lady, if you flie, being ſo able to deſend,
〈◊〉 ſhall ſuſpect you have an ambuſh here:
• 'le make good this ground, proud of my purchaſe;
I know 'tis of ſuch value, that the reſtoring
Will preſs you to another parly.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Why think you ſo? To loſe your company withall,
Will make the loſs of any thing I have about me inſenſible.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Make good your word; change but your maidenhead
For this; and if I ever trouble you again—

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: O inſolence! can you believe that ſuch a jewel
Is reſerv'd for you? you may as well by your ſmall
Single valor hope to ſurpriſe the ſtrongeſt fort.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Nay perhaps ſooner, Lady; may be you
Know the firſt impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I know 'tis impoſsible you ſhould be other
Then a rude Soldier.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: True, whilſt you are an uncivil Lady,
'Tis wiſdom to frame our ſelves like to the company
We wiſh to keep.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Indeed I muſt confeſs you put upon me in this ſeeming
Cenſure, a mighty obligation: your words imply as much,
As if I would be wicked, you for conformity
Would be ſo too; in troth I do not doubt it:
But that you can as well conform yourſelf to better
Images, is that I have no reaſon to believe.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: From theſe your hard opinions, yet in a milder phraſe
Expreſt, judge charitably, that my diſreſpect
Is likewiſe leſſening: And certain, Lady,
So many beauties as ſhew themſelves about your
Perſon, were gifts the Gods repented of,
Which made them place a ſoul whoſe pride might tel the world
It was a goodly Temple built to ſhew their power,
But not to ſhare their adoration.

sp.speaker: Sel:
sp.l: I ſee you are an experienc'd Soldier,
And are not without ſtratagems, making your
Battery on the weakeſt ſide. You praiſe the beauty
Of my perſon, and diſpraiſe my mind:
That too for what we almoſt hold a vertue, (pride)
Grant us but fair, whate're we ſeem, it is
Impoſsible we ſhould be angry.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: No more of theſe ingenious confeſsions, Lady,
Le • t I become Apoſtate from my old religion,
And believe there may be other beauties in your ſex
Then what the eye ſurveys.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I am wondrous ſorry if I have ſaid any thing
To gain your good opinion.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: O fear not, Lady, I am not ſo much taken yet
To trouble you with lamentable verſes,
Or blow the candle out with ſighs: breaking my buttons
After a full meal, • s the higheſt I can reach to: I aſſure you,
Methinks that Princely pattern is ſcarce worth
The following. The King!

div.stage: Enter Old King, Cleon, Senor, Stremon.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: I ſee you loſe no opportunity to become
Gracious with the Ladies, I like it well;
Your brother's more unnatural, and courts the men.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: The men of action, ſir, he does indeed.

sp.speaker: O. K:
sp.l: The men of turbulencie and ambition:
But I ſhall check his and their haughty ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Cle:
sp.l: Let what you do, ſir, be with moderation,
He's of a fierce nature, and can ill endure
Reproof, however juſt.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Fierce nature! ſhall I obſerve a boy?
I am his father and his King; and what he fails
In duty to the one, the other ſhall inforce him
To confeſs and ſatisfie.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: 'Tis juſt indeed.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: And being ſo, I mſt not fear to let him know
His faults.
Now ſir, what would you with us?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I muſt not hope, ſir, you will grant the ſuit
I come to move, until I ſee your brow more calm▪

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: If you miſlike theſe looks, remove the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Perhaps it is not, ſir, in me, but in your ſelf:
There are ſome waters where the billows riſe
Though no croſs winds do blow; Earthquakes are in
Another kind the ſame, the cauſes dark,
And yet not more then are your groundleſs diſtaſtes
From whence this tempeſt grows.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Your words explain your actions, and your actions them:
From both you do conclude my weakneſs,
And your innocence from fault.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: The latter is, and ſtill hath been my ſtudy:
Shew me wherein, ſir, I have err'd,
In what I have deſerved your hard opinion:
Till when I would not, ſir, by asking pardon
Create a guilt.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: I know you rather do expect that I ſhould ſue to you,
And I will do it. Pray give me leave to be
A King ſome few years more; you know
I ſhall not trouble you when your turn comes.

sp.speaker: Clorind.
sp.l: Dear ſervant, I find my ſelf not well.

sp.speaker: Clari.
sp.l: Heaven forbid!

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Sir, I do find your age is wrought upon
By ſome unworthy men, who for their own ends
Keep me from that intereſt nature and reaſon
Ought to yield me in your love; which ſince
I cannot hope from you by my true ſervice,
(Still miſinterpreted) I ſcorn to ſeek
To gain it by a flattery of them.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: I know thoſe whom I favour,
Are for that cauſe the objects of your hate.
And 'tis not ſtrange, that having forfeited
Much of your own obedience, you ſhould miſlike
Their faithfulneſs.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I ſee, ſir, 'tis in vain to plead a cauſe
Already judg'd againſt me: Cunning
Weighs down my intereſt in your blood.
I came, ſir, with a hope to obtain ſome ſuits
For others, which now reaſon commands me to let fall,
And rather beg what I am only likely to obtain.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: What's that, I pray?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Your leave ſir, to retire
My ſelf, to free your Majeſty
And me both from diſturbance.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: You ask and grant your ſelf, 'tis well.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Sir, that retirement he intends,
Grows not from duty, but ambition.
Out of that cloud ere long he means to break
Forth gloriouſly; the world, ſir, cannot admit
More then one Sun; and he's reſolved to ſhine,
Though nature ſuffer in it.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: It was ſtill my fear, you have no other proofs
But your conjecture.

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: I would I had not, ſir; but ſuch my love is to your Majeſty.
That to preſerve the Royal ſtem, I muſt not fear
To hazard breaking a corrupted branch.
At more convenience I ſhall inform you.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: The King is old and ſickly, inconſtant by nature;
And we muſt, whilſt this heat of paſsion laſts,
Work for our ſafety by the Princes ruine.
If he ſhould come to reign, our power, if not our, lives,
Is at end; but both are likely to be ſafe
And proſperous under his brother Clarimant,
Who is of a ſoft and gentle nature,
Apt to be governed.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Eſpecially when it ſhall appear
We have both will and power to ſerve him
In attaining to the Crown.

sp.speaker: Senor.
sp.l: Perhaps Lord Cleon does reſolve the ſame,
And he's man of power and blood; we being join'd
How can we miſs our end,
Since the whole Court does on us three depend?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Dear Lady, do not welcom ſadneſs thus:
Truſt me, it is an ill mannered gueſt,
And ſeldom leaves us; though we grow weary
Of its company, and wiſh it gone.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Not be ſenſible when there is cauſe,
Would ſhew ſtupidity.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Wife men affirm there is no cauſe of ſorrow
But for offending heaven.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Theſe ſtrengths of mind you Men enjoy,
Are certain to our weaker ſex denied.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Alas, but I am none of thoſe;
For if you grieve, I cannot be exempted.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Would I had kept my troubles to my ſelf then!
I would not have them grow by being guilty
Of infecting you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: A ſympathie with you for what concerns my ſelf,
Though it be grief to me, is pleaſing.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: I muſt not ſay ſo much for you;
And yet this is the only time I ever wiſht
Your abſence: pray ſir be pleaſed to leave me
To my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: And 'tis the only time I ever durſt ſeem
Diſobedient; be but your ſelf, and I will leave you
But whilſt you are in bondage,
A priſoner to your grief, I muſt not.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Ye are cruel in you kindneſs, ſir,
And tie me faſter: A ranſom of my tears
Being plentifully paid, perhaps may free me;
And whilſt you ſtay, ſhame bars me from the trial.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I would not ſee you weep; for if your tears
Were ſhed in vain, it would call in queſtion
My religion, as having paid my vows
To powers inſenſible.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Take heed, ſweet Prince, you do not jeſt your ſelf
Into idolatry, and over-act that part you perſonate,
To pleaſe a brother; that were a guilt
Neither your tears not mine can expiate,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I fear your warning comes too late for me.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I hope I underſtand you not.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You do not Lady, nor I my ſelf,
For I have ſpoke I know not what: ſhame forces
An obedience, which your commands could not.
All peace of mind wait on you.

div.l: Stay brother, whither ſo faſt? I came to ſeek you,
Stay—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Not for the world, and pray henceforth
Let us not injure truth.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: What means this?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: My Lord, I know not well, ſome diſcontent.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Are we alone? is there no other eye but that of
Heaven beholds us?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: None that I know.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Bleſt opportunity! ſtill I am fearful; for your ſake
I would not have our loves diſcover'd now by chance
Which with ſuch art and care hath been ſo long
Conceal'd from all men but my brother.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I would it had been ſo from him too, ſir:

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Why do you fear he will diſcover us?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: O no ſir, but—

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: But what?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: The gods were witneſs enough for me, ſir,
'Twere my glory, were it known; if in your fortune
But a ſlave, I ſhould with joy proclaim to all
The world what your intereſt were in me:
But for your ſake, conſidering how you father
Frowns already, I ſcarce dare to my ſelf
Whiſper the joy of being yours.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: My father! let not that trouble you,
We will be free as he ere long, and our commands
Better obeyed.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: O ſpeak not again my fears! how ſir? better obeyed!

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: By thoſe that love me, and will live and die with me.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Die with you, ſir! why ſhould that come in queſtion?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Only as an expreſsion of my friends affection.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: But ſir, were all men what they ſeem,
That which I fear you do intend, is that
Which heaven cannot approve; take heed of diſobedience, ſir.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Why doeſt thou plead againſt thy ſelf, againſt thy joyes
And mine? Now as I am, I dare not look on theſe
Bright eyes, the comforts of my life, nor touch this hand,
Theſe lips, not ſpeak but by the aſsiſtance
Of my brother.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: This is a freedom, ſir, modeſty could not allow
Did we oft meet; and as it is, do not again
Expect it.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l:
Why, deareſt, are you ſo nice? you do no •
love me:
Your hand you will not ſure refuſe me.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I ſhall, ſir, if you preſume upon an opportu • nity▪

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: You never did deny that favor to my brothe •
As my ſubſtitute.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: It is confeſt, and that in publike too,
More willingly I there would grant him any mode ••
Favor, then here to you in private.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: That's ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Do we not often give thoſe praiſes to a perſo •
Abſent, which modeſty would make us bluſh
To ſpeak unto himſelf?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: It ſeems I muſt be only favored by attorny▪

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Not ſo; the mind being the nobleſt part,
I'ſt not enough if that be happy?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Yes, if it could ſubſiſt without a body:
Which ſince it cannot, deareſt miſtres, if you'll be juſt,
The beauties of your perſon muſt in ſome meaſure
Satisfie the flames that they create.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Sir, I believe you will not think 'tis a forc'd modeſty
That I put on; though I ſhould tell you I am not pleas'd
At all to be alone with you, yet how much
I do love you, it were in vain to ſpeak.
That love enjoins, as you will keep your faith
To me, not to diſturb the quiet of your Father
And this Kingdom, likely to be yours;
Do not expect to find them faithful in the time
To come, to whom you ſhall teach falſhood
By your own example.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Happily I have no ſuch deſign; we are ingrate
To fortune and to Love, in ſpending this happy
Opportunity on any other ſubject
Then what may tend unto his glory.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I ſee, Sir, I muſt leave you, or my modeſty.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Dear do not frown; pardon thoſe faults
Your beauties and my love engage me in.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Should I grant that for an excuſe ſufficient,
Where ſhould we find a guilty or immodeſt perſon,
Since all immoderate deſires do find a beauty
In their object, which promiſes a pleaſure
By enjoying? My love then yours is of a purer
Kind, and fit it ſhould, as growing from
A nobler cauſe, your greater merit:
Be witneſs heaven, I never yielded yet
To any thought or motion, wherein your happineſs
Had not precedence.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Should I pretend to what you do appropriate,
The greateſt love, 'twould ſhew preſumption.
Yet here I offer what you dare not perform
To me, a free unlimited diſpoſing
Of my perſon and my will.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I take you at your word; and though your
Humble ſervant, as a Miſtreſs do impoſe
Theſe two commands: Be modeſt in your love,
And patient in your expectation of a Crown;
Let all things be mature and ripen'd to perfection,
Then they are ſweet and lovely; but on the
Contrary, many infirmities accompany
Abortive births, ſeldom or never laſting.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Sure you will not leave me thus.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Yes ſir, I muſt,
The greatneſs of my love commands me,
Remember your promiſe.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: You do expreſs it ſtrangely;
Would you ſtay longer, if you loved me leſs?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: With much more confidence. I tremble, ſir, leſt
Some unwelcom perſon ſhould find us here
Alone; if there were company with whom you
Might diſcourſe, I ſhould ſtand by and hear you
With delight, look on you with much more:
Now apprehenſion of diſcovery takes away
All pleaſure from me.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: If we muſt ever live with this conſtraint upon us,
Where are the joys of love? It reſts not ſure
Alone in being beloved, but in poſſeſſion.
He that deſpairs in love, hath a more happy fate
Then I: You do not love me ſure; what have I
More then words to build my faith upon?
If you have pitty in you, be more kind,
Or free me from my laſt engagement.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Not for a million.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Truſt me, I ſhall not hold my ſelf ſufficiently
Obliged, unleſs I ſeal my promiſe on your lip.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: He that will break his word, no other tie
Can hold him.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Yet never any fearful Creditor
(Such you appear to be) refuſed an Obligation.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: This is the laſt you ever as a Miſtreſs
Shall receive from me.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: May your laſt words prove happily prophetick!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Think on your promiſe, ſir.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I do; ſo ſweet was the engagement,
That whilſt I think on it, even then
It prompts me to the breaking, the only way
For to attain a greater bliſs in her. Promiſes
Made in prejudice of Love, I ſhould be moſt profane
To keep; nor can ſhe be offended, however fear
And modeſty in her forbad me to attempt.
Power, and her dear Embraces, are alike
The objects of my ſoul: ſhall danger then make me retire?
No, danger thruſts me on, and tells me there's no • ſafety
But in arms, which well imployed, cancels my fault
Unto my father, and ſmooths Clorinda's brow:
• he cannot be ſo cruel to herſelf to frown
On diſobedience that preſents a Crown.

div.head: Act. 2. Scaen. 1.

sp.speaker: • lar.
sp.l: O Fool! for ever thou haſt forfeited thy bliſs,
She never will endure to hear thee ſpeak,
Or look upon her more. What falſhood
• uſt ſhe think me guilty of? I am ſo ſenſible
Of my offence, that though ſhe would admit me,
• durſt never ſee her more: How poor a value then
• ears life!

div.l: Brother!

sp.speaker: Clar▪
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: How ſtrangely you are alter'd!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You do not erre ſir, I was not wont to be thus ſad.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Nor do I hope you will continue long ſo;
Your grief may prove infectious, pray ſhake it off,
You ſhall not elſe keep company with my Clorinda.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I never will, ſir.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: How, brother?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: This ſadneſs will not leave me.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Come, by all our intereſts I conjure you
• peak freely what troubles you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Then ſir, in ſhort, you have undone me.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I! deareſt brother.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Yes, you: Did you not enjoin
•• at I ſhould make in publike addreſs to your Miſtreſs,
〈◊〉 which received opinion you might be freer
〈◊〉 your love?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Had you engaged me in the like,
I ſhould with joy have done it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: My care was ſuch to do it to the life,
That I am really become what I did perſonate;
Are not you then the cauſe that I am miſerable?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: What do I hear! can there be truth in this
If it be ſo, ſpeak it again.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: 'Tis that I never muſt deny,
I love her more then I do life.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Or faith, or honour, do you not?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l:
Sure I believe nothing with her can ſtand i •
competion long.
Yet I will never ſee her more.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: It is not fit you ſhould. What do I feel
Can the meer name of Rival trouble me?
Yes, with the addition that he is my brother.
But whither am I falling? Aſſiſt me Reaſon,
Let me but weigh my Miſtreſſes unequal'd beauty
And her greater merit, and that muſt prove
Both his excuſe, and my aſſurance.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I fear, ſir, you are angry; Not that I valu •
Any danger, but that I would not have you ſo unjuſ •

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Truſt me I am not, brother,
I will admit you as a friendly Rival:
Make her inconſtant once, and I ſhall gladly quit her •

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Had you ſo mean a thought of her or me,
It were an injury I could not ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Come, come, upon my life I have not.
Some buſineſs, brother, of the higheſt importance

Commands me from you, perhaps from Court er •
long.
And that I may aſſure you of my love and truſt,
Carry from me this Picture to my deareſt Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l:
Sir, I beſeech you pardon me; I would no •
ſee her
When I may avoid it; there's too much danger
In the object.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Remember ſhe's your Brothers Miſtreſs, that will protect you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I never did forget, pray ſend it by ſome other.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I ſhall believe you do indeed intend to wooe
My miſtreſs from me, ſince you refuſe to appear to her
My friend and meſſenger.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Sir, I will do it; but henceforth never miſdoubt
The ſtrengths you hold upon me; for I in it
• o break a reſolution equal to a vow.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: How hard a fate is mine! to what croſs actions
• oth our paſſions move? I flie from what I wiſh;
Yet to aſſiſt anothers flame, I grant what
so my own I had denied. Oh no, it is not thus;
• or every action rightly weighed, it will be found,
Our own advantage is the proper center
Where all lines meet: For if I tru • y apprehended
• diſcontent from ſeeing her, I ſhould not ſure
• ave yielded to the inforcement of my brother.
• o, 'tis with me as with thoſe men who are
• y nature ſtrongly tempted to ſome luſt,
•• as'd in the ſin, yet grant no guilt,
Only alleadging for excuſe, They muſt.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Sweet Selina, it is not now that I ſhall need
• o make a declaration of my love,
• ou long have known the engagement of my heart.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: My Lord, my obligations are ſo great,
• hat you may juſtly claim the utmoſt of my power
• oward the accompliſhment of your deſires.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I have been too unthankful to ſo true a friend;
But be aſſured that thou ſhalt have my beſt
Of fortunes with me; in the mean time wear this
To keep me in thy memory.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: It needs not ſir, I have already too many teſt •• moni •
Of your favor, to forget.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: When was Prince Clarimant with thy Lad •

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: When was he not? I fear, ſir, her affection
To him is ſo rooted, that it will grow for ever.
Yet I have uſed thoſe arts you taught me,
And ſome female practiſes of mine, but all in vain.
But ſir, deſpair not, ſince as yet you never
Did make known your love to her; and were ſhe
My mind, ſhe ſoon would make a difference
Betwixt a boy, a child, and ſuch a man as you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Friendſhip doth blind thee, more then • o does me:
The froſt I wear upon my locks, will keep
My fire from kindling in her breaſt;
Whilſt equal youth and beauty in the Prince
Gives nouriſhment unto a mutual flame.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I hope it will—

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Yet prethee ſay that I would ſpeak with h •
And have a care none overhear our conference.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l:
My Lord, I ſhall endeavour it; ſhe's now 〈◊〉
the garden.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: It is not love alone unto the Princeſs perſo •
I know I cannot be ſo faithleſs to my own deſigns,
No, 'tis her intereſt to the Crown engages me
As much as does her beauty or her wit:
And yet ſhe holds by thoſe, when I do ſee,
Or hear her ſpeak, great power upon me.
But I muſt watch my flame, no ſpark let fall
That may give any light of my affection to her,
In a third perſon I muſt try her,
Since ſhe's of humane race, a woman to her moth ••
Whether from her be not derived ſome ſeeds
Of the firſt female weakneſſes, ambition and
Inconſtancie; which if I find, I'll nouriſh them,
And in their growth my hopes; but if I ſee
Such powerful charm no alteration move,
She claims my adoration, cures my love.
She comes, be firm my reſolution,
The ſplendor of her eyes is powerful; already
My deſigns meet with confuſion: Love gives the lye
To my ambition, triumphs o're my diſcretion,
And tels me that a Crown's an aiery nothing
Compared with the poſſeſſing of her perſonal
Beauty: what wonders will the magick of
Her tongue perform?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: What means this?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: 'Tis beſt I ſhould at once profeſs my love,
And in her ſcorn receive a glorious death—
Stay, let me be a King firſt; and then to offer
Up my ſelf to my great Deity,
Brings no diſhonor to her ſhrine.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: My Lord, did you not deſire to ſpeak with me?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Madam, I did; and the affair is of ſuch weight,
That though I had conſulted with my ſelf before,
I durſt not utter it without a ſecond thought,
And none but your dear ſelf to hear it.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Leave us.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Madam, amongſt thoſe many whom your perfections
Have devoted to your ſervice, though not ſo happy
As with others to expreſs my zeal,
There's none, without exception I dare ſpeak it,
Would ſooner undertake, or hazard more to ſerve you.
This if you can believe, I dare enlarge my ſelf:
If not, I muſt be ſatisfied with this expreſſion.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: My Lord, if I be not miſtaken, you are a frien •
To thoſe whom all know I do value highly; that,
Were I ignorant of your own worth,
Is argument enough for my eſteem and truſt.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I here do call the Gods to witneſs,

That all my ſtudy, all my friendſhip tends to you •
advantage:
Nor is the Prince at all conſiderable to me,
But as he is your ſervant; but for your ſake
I wiſh he were the the Monarch of the world.
For, how ſo much perfection can be ordain'd
To bleſs a Subjects bed, comes not within
The compaſs of my faith; and Prince Clarimant
Is never like to be a King.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: To what tends this?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: But had your love been plac'd upon his brother
As his is upon you, ere long your beauties
Might have found their proper foil, a Crown,
To ſet • hem off as a bright conſtellation, there
All eyes might look on you with wonder
And delight; but in a Subjects name, your glorie
Are obſcured.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Either the Prince, as being his friend,
Hath made diſcovery to him of our loves,
Or he hath found cauſe to ſuſpect.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l:
Madam, I ſee what I have ſpoke, begets you •
trouble.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs it, ſir; can it do leſs,
When I ſhall hear a perſon of your merit,
A friend as you profeſs, perſwading me
To quit my faith for the vain expectation
Of a Crown.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Madam, the Crown will ſoon be his, as certai •
As he loves you, and both as certain as I live.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: It is impoſſible that Prince Agenor he ſhould love,
And never ſpeak his paſſion.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: No more then it was in me.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: How ſir, in you?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Madam, I will confeſs a ſecret to you,
• burn with a more zealous conſuming fire
Then ever yet was kindled in a mortals breaſt;
Have often ſeen my Miſtreſs, ſpoke to her,
Had opportunities alone, as now with you:
Yet ſuch was my reſpect to her, I never durſt
Expreſs my paſſion▪ Then, Madam, from the purity
Of my affection, judge of the Prince,
And reward his ſufferings.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I muſt try him; Can this be poſſible?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Iove ſtrike me with his thunder,
If what I now have ſaid, be not a truth:

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: My Lord, if it be thus, I ſhall at leaſt find pitty
For his ſufferings: my beſt of wiſhes too
For your ſucceſs in love.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Would you be pleas'd, when I ſhall let you know
Her name, to be my advocate? I cannot doubt
My happineſs.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Sure he means me.—Alas, my Lord, what you deſire
I ſhould perform for any worthy perſon,
Much more for you, ſince what I ſhall perſwade
Muſt tend for certain to her happineſs.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Can I ask more? ſhe courts me to diſcover.

div.l: Divineſt Lady,
The Prince your ſervant deſires admittance.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Hell take him! Madam, be pleas'd to grant me
The honor of your hand as an aſſurance
Of your promis'd favor.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: If you believe I have the power to ſerve you
In your love, name but the time and perſon,
I am ready to aſſiſt you, were it this minute.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I ſhould too much preſume upon your favo •
The Prince your ſervant being ſo near attending.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Do not miſtake ſir, he may ſtay.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l:
Why am I fearful? dare I believe my ſelf 〈◊〉
happy,
That you would miſs the Prince's company a minute •
To pleaſure me?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Yes by my life, two minutes; nor is't in 〈◊〉
Meer curioſity to know the loves of others,
But that I hold my ſelf obliged no longer
To be ignorant of one whoſe worth and beauty
Hath the force to ad your conqueſt to Lov's triumph
Yours who have been ſtill obſerved victorious
In the ſubduing every other paſſion.
To force an inclination, is an act of power,
Where every common beauty can ſubdue the amorous.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Not to have yielded homage here, had been a flat
Rebellion, ſince all hearts are a tribute due
To her perfections; which juſtice will inforce you
To confeſs, when you know how much ſhe doth
Reſemble you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: 'Tis plain he loves, rather would have me think ſo,
My Lord, your laſt words give me cauſe to doubt,
Not ſo much your attaining, as the over-value
Of the purchaſe; and that I may not have a leſs eſteem
Of you, I muſt confeſs I do not wiſh to know her now.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Madam, the Prince!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: How ſhall I underſtand this dark Enigma?
Hope, or deſpair? 'tis time muſt cleer it.
Sir, I preſume to have that intereſt in you,
You will not be offended at your ſtay.
For the injury, name your own ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: So kind,
Madam, to me who have no other merit
But obedience, how can there be an injury?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: In this unjuſt acknowledgment, much modeſty appears:
How winning muſt your words and actions be,
When they are accompanied with truth?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: That only muſt be truth with me,
Which you are pleas'd to have ſo; I will not own
A faculty that prompts me to a contradiction:
Yet never could I yield to my own praiſe,
But as I am dignified in being your creature.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: In being ſo abſolutely mine, you make me richer
In my own eſteem, then all additions which the world
Can yield beſides.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: This Lady can diſſemble; but with whom ſhe does ſo,
I am yet to learn. It is not fit I ſhould diſturb
This harmony; the God of love is hovering
Not far off, delighted with the muſick
Of theſe melting accents: For I, a profeſt oppoſite
To all his ſweetneſs, have forfeited my manners by my ſtay.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: Not ſo, my Lord; the exceſs of kindneſs
I have ſhewed Prince Clarimant,
Muſt clear all ſuſpition in this Lord,
If he had any, that I love Agenor.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Sir, be happy in this Princeſs to my wiſh,
Which hath a latitude as great as you can
Think. Your Father by my means (if I may boaſt
A ſervice to my Princely friend) highly approves
The match.—
All happineſs attend you both.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: How fortune mocks me!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Struck with a ſudden ſadneſs, ſir!
Call for my ſervants, I'll go to Court,
Have you any ſervice to command me, ſir?

sp.speaker: Clar:
sp.l: Madam, I ſee you fain would change the Scene:
How ſoon are you weary of his company,
To whom juſt now you did profeſs ſo much?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Not weary, ſir, but yet I hope
That you have not forgot to whom
All thoſe profeſſions were intended.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Yet they were ſpoke to me, the words accompanied
With proper accents, your eyes, to ſpeak Loves language;
And here before Lord Cleon with more perſwaſive
Eloquence then ever.

sp.speaker: Clo:
sp.l: 'Tis true, it makes me almoſt bluſh to think
How much I courted you: Heaven knows
I could not for the world have ſpoke
Or lookt ſo on your brother; the reaſon was,
I feared that Cleon did ſuſpect whom I did
Love indeed.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: And you to cozen him, uſed me ſo overkindly,
At firſt I doubt not but you laid the plot
Of thus diſguiſing your affection.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: You ſpeak as if you did repent the obligation
You have laid upon your brother and my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Do you eſteem it one?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: A great one, ſir, believe.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Heaven knows I not repent it then;
But can you think that when you look and ſpeak
With paſſion, whoever hears muſt not be moved,
And in deſpight of duty wiſh
Though dare not hope, that he were the object
Of that paſſion:

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Oh miſery!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: How could I then, to whom they were addreſt,
Having withall a ſympathie of blood,
But find joy as a brother, at firſt no more,
Which warranted for juſt, at laſt that pleaſure
Ere I was aware betrayed to me a deeper
And more peculiar ſenſe of happineſs in you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Add not that vanity unto your falſhood,
To hope from me a common eſtimation after this.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Add not injuſtice to your cruelty,
To hate where you ſhould pitty: The injunction
Did proceed from you, you are the firſt
And the immediate cauſe that I am miſerable:
Which makes me often doubt, ſince it proceeds from you,
Whether it be a crime or no. When I ſhall find it
Such, you ſhall not need to frown or threaten
Puniſhment by hating me, once confident you do,
Without a cauſe I know you cannot;
I will inflict more, then happily you will wiſh
I ſhould.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: The Judge and the accuſed ſo neer allied,
As we are to our ſelves, no crime is great enough
For puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Madam, you much miſtake; I cannot be the Judge.
That am am the Plaintiff: for who does, at leaſt juſtly
Can complain of injury but I? How is my love,
Since a requital is not in my wiſh, a wrong
To you or to my brother?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: No! why did you by complaining
Make me know your paſſion?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Now you have named my guilt,
Alas I find I have too much approved that law
Which ſays, no man is bound to be his own accuſer.
You are the proper Judge, truth ſpeaks in you,
Let your ſevereſt cenſure fall, and by the Gods
I am your faithful Executioner.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Then—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Stay, firſt receive this Picture of my happy Brother,
Sent from himſelf, the occaſion of your trouble,
Now, I ſpeak not this in my excuſe,
To raiſe your pitty up againſt your juſtice;
For I at laſt was pleas'd in the imployment.
Nay, now profeſs to you and all the world,
Whilſt I have life, I ſhall adore you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: And muſt I ſentence you then,
Like to a deſperate perſon that hath done
Some wickedneſs ſo great, for which the happineſs
Of ſorrow is denied.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You muſt for what concerns my loving you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Then hear a ſentence proper to the guilt:
Your eyes and tongue, which did betray your vertue,
Muſt never meet in me their objects more.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Miſery! never to look or ſpeak to you,
Is that my doom?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: It is juſtly inflicted.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I not diſpute; but ſhall it never be revok'd?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: It is from me inviolate by all the Gods;
You may to morrow break it, and I look you ſhould.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs, what ere I do reſolve,
'Tis not unlike I ſhould.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I thought no leſs.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: But Madam, I will never ſee to morrow,
Death is more welcom then to diſobey you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Hold ſir.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: How long?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Sure you are not in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Not in earneſt! death could have brought no pain
• ike this; I ſee I did ſo well diſſemble once,
That I am thought to do ſo ſtill.
This is an injury ſo great, it frees me
From diſobedience.

div.stage: Offers his ſword agen upon himſelf:

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Oh hold, as you doe love me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: As you do hate me, let me die.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: No, you miſtake,
Or would by death fruſtrate your puniſhment.
If you were dead, no longer ſhould remain
The ſenſe of your offence, or my juſt hatred
For it: Live to be ſorry, that way expiate
Your guilt, I do not ſay your puniſhment.
But if you kill yourſelf on this occaſion,
Making me acceſſary to your murder,
• call the Gods to witneſs I will revenge it
By making you like guilty of your Brothers death,
For I will never ſee him more: how horrid
Should I look dreſt in a ſcarlet robe
Dyed in your blood.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: All theſe are trifles, whilſt your (juſt)
Yet moſt hard ſentence reſts upon me,
Never to ſee you more.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Would vertue could permit to make your noble ſufferings leſs:
Your love might be received, and yet your perſon
Never gain acceſs.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O cruel pitty!

div.stage: Enter Cleon with a Letter and Papers.

sp.speaker: Cle. reads.
sp.l: Meet me with all the forces you ca •
Raiſe, at Laſſent on the frontiers of Germany; th •
Imployment you then ſhall know.
—As I could wiſh.
You Powers, why ſhould I be thought a perſon
Capable of his temptation? but there's no help,
He that hath loſt his own vertue, may well expect
To make another falſe. The Rocks, whoſe conſtanc •
Denies an entrance to the beating waves,
Though they want motion, yet in their firmneſs
Seem to take revenge by caſting the attempting
Billows with diſperſt drops upon the movers
Face: So though all motion be denied
Againſt the perſon of the Prince, from reverence
To the Father, yet here I may revenge
My injuries, and manifeſt the vanity of his deſign
In this diſperſion.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Hold, hold, why do you tear the paper •

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l:
What do you mean ſir? 'twas but a trivia •
Note,
Howe'r the impertinencie of the Sender
Moved me.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: A trivial Note! can thy faith ſtile that ſo,
Wherein my ſafety is concern'd?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: How ſir, your ſafety!

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Come, come, diſſemble not; we will be both reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Reveng'd, on whom?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: On my falſe Son: No more I ſay,
For know, your tenderneſs hath trencht upon your faith,
I muſt know every circumſtance,
Dare nott hide it from me:

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Remember, ſir, he is your ſon, your heir,
A Prince in whom your peoples hopes and joyes are fixt:
• ay theſe cloſe to your heart to move your pitty;
And then what my unhappy memory contains
Of what was writ.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Nay, if a Councellor ſuſpect his memory,
His Princes ſafety at the ſtake, 'tis fit he truſt
His own care, I'll gather theſe.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Your pardon, Royal ſir; you ſhall know every
Circumſtance: but ſir, remember ſtill
How dear your ſon is to your people,
Loſe not their love by cruelty to him.

sp.speaker: O. K:
sp.l: Not dearer ſure to them then you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Nay, then this be my witneſs of the contrary—
• o, read, till it kill all nature in thee,
And corrupt thy brain,
• uch loſs to him muſt prove my greateſt gain.

div.head: Act. 3. Scaen. 1.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: ALl theſe you ſay are ready.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: All on my knowledg; there's no other fear,
• ut that your troops will be too full. Might I have
• iven advice, ere this you had been gone;
here's danger in your ſtay, ſo many flock hither
• rom the Court, your houſe is no way able
• o contain them, and ſome no doubt that come
〈◊〉 Spies.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: To morrow early I'll be gone, I muſt this night
Bid farewell to my deareſt Miſtreſs.—Now.
O ſir, I have rid; my horſe fell dead juſt at the door▪
You are betrayed, ſir, proclaim'd a Traitor,
Your Fathers Guard I overtook.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: By this time they are at the gates.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: O heavens! my fears are faln upon us.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: What's to be done?

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Let us make good the gates againſt them▪

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: There's none dares touch my perſon.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Believe it not ſir, there is no fafety:
Your Fathers jealouſies are wrought to a ſtrange
Height, and thoſe whom you leaſt ſuſpect
I fear conſpire your ruine, to advance
Your brother to the Crown.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Who do you mean?

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Lord Cleon.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: It is impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: I ſaw Prince Clarimant and him together
And Cleon's words were to the Captain of the guar •
Bring him alive or dead.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Sir, be adviſed, there is no ſafety

In the Kingdom for you, until this ſtorm blow ove •
▪

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: What, ſhall I flie?

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Rather then fall. I know there's thouſan •

Will live and dye with with you, but here they a •
not.

div.l: The Guard, Sir, do approach the houſe on every ſid •

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Make ſure the gates.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: That will not do't; fire ſoon will ope • ther •
—Down with them, Fire the gates,

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Hark!

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Let's force our paſſage through them. [They claſh their ſwords within.]

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.p: My friends, this care is needleſs; why do you hold me? I am not mad.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Mad, ſir, we do not think it.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.p: Nor can I ſwim, I do aſſure you.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.p: Then you are ſure I cannot ſcape your hands, as the Prince did.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: No ſir, we'll look to you for that: Bring him away before the King.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.p: Before the King! of what will you accuſe me?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: For being acceſſary of the Princes flight.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: O 'tis well, then we'll ev'n hang for company.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: For company!

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Even ſo, if I be acceſſary, you let him ſcape.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Why, could we help it, when he leapt into the river?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Had your Zeal been ſo hot to ſerve the King, as you do now make ſhew of, You would have dows'd in over head and ears.
What, drown our ſelves?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p:
Yes, any thing in zeal: My zeal to juſtice ſhall hang all you and my ſelf Too, for in my conſcience we deſerve it; what, ſhrin •
for a little water?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: He tels us true, our fault will be eſteem'd as great as his.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Come, come along my friends, we muſt before the King.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Very pretty.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: You will not find ſo, when my moſt nob •
Lord Cleon ſhall with the King
Judge of your actions.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.l: Well Captain, we acquit you; I find indeed
We ſhould be fools to accuſe each other.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Speak for your ſelves, &c.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l:
Urge nought in his excuſe, he's a bo •
Traitor,
And he ſhall know his birth is no excuſe
For diſobedience.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Sir, I dare pawn my life, my brother neve • di •
Nor does intend ill to your Royal perſon.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l:
If it were ſo, am not I wounded in m •
Miniſters?
This natural tenderneſs of thine, a Brothers,
Condemns him moſt unnatural to me a Father.
Now ſpeak, is the Traitor coming to aſſault us?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: No ſir, but he is ſcap'd our hands.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: How? ſcap'd!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: He reſolutely made his paſſage through u •
And we purſuing to take him, he with Lucidor
Leapt into the river, and ſwam to a ſmall pi • ace
Of his own, that always lay there for his
Pleaſure, in which they are put to ſea.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l:
With all ſpeed make to the ſhore, and ſe •
what courſe
They hold: if he ſir in deſpair ſhould go into New • ſtre •
With whoſe King you now have difference
About the ſtaying of your ſhips of treaſure,
And the Iſle of Cires; no doubt much danger
Threatens your ſelf and State; to prevent which,
Straight raiſe an Army, and make Prince Clarimant
Your General, that being in readineſs,
You may prevent any attempt Agenor
Or the enemy can make againſt you.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Be all things ordered by thy faith and judgment,
Thy care muſt be my preſervation,
I do commit all power into thy hands:
Hearken to him, my deareſt Clarimant,
In what he ſhall adviſe thee; my age
And griefs, I find, will quickly wear me out.
• 'll to my chamber: Give order, careful,
Faithful Cleon.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Yes, I ſhall be careful to take order,
An order with you all, Father and ſons.
Now my deſigns work proſperouſly;
Only the late diſcovery that Selina made,
Does trouble me; Agenor, not Clarimant
My Rival, is by her beloved: but all
Do love Clorinda; yet now Agenor's gone,
She happily may change her love to Clarimant,
Who is opinion now ſtands faireſt for the Crown:
Rather I hope by this ſhe hates him
As the cauſe of all Agenor's miſery:
So far Selina is by me inſtructed
• o inſinuate, whom I of late have wrought
To a belief that I do love her perſon,
But Clorinda's quality and title,
As being thoſe ſteps by which I hope of aſcend
The throne—See where ſhe comes! ſpeak my ſweet
Agent; how moves our plot?

div.stage: Enter Selina, with a Letter ſeal'd and writ out.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Not well, too faſt I fear.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Obeying your directions, my Lady hath contracted
• o much hatred againſt Prince Clarimant,
• he ſcarcely can endure to hear him named,
Reſolves never to ſee him more.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Is not this well? 'tis all as I could wiſh?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Thus far 'tis true: but now Agenor's gon •
She ſo much apprehends the importunity
Of Prince Clarimants affection, that ſhe's reſolv •
Paſt all perſwaſion, in a diſguiſe
To ſeek for the Agenor, which if ſhe find,
She ſatisfies her love, however cures her fears.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: My cunning hath undone me:
Thus chance oft triumphs over wiſdom.
But what? there is ſome remedy in every ill—
Let me think it what diſguiſe: ſoft, may ſhe not
With you diſſemble, as you with her?
And ſhe does yet love Clarimant, and not Ageno •

sp.speaker: Sel
sp.l: No, I have that here does aſſure me
She hates Prince Clarimant.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: What is't▪ a Letter? O let me ſee it!

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: By no means ſir, you cannot cloſe it
But the Prince will find it hath been broken.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: You do not know my skill.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I need not truſt it, upon my life I'll tell yo •
Every word that it contains, ſhe read it to me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Nay then I fear ſhe did abuſe you,
All Lovers are diſſemblers, and ſhe I fear
Is a cunning one.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: What ſhe hath done, I know not;
But now her ſorrows and her paſſions
Are ſo rais'd, the heart's tranſparent.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: There may be greateſt art.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Such broken ſighs, and floods of tears,
Agenor's name ſtill call'd upon,
Gives me aſſurance of her love to him.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Change but the name, the griefs may ſtill 〈◊〉
Counterfeit: I ſigh and vow Clorinda,
Inſtructed by ambition; but yet my heart
Is more Selina's.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Well, my Lord, you may abuſe me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Prethee let me ſee the Letter.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: The words are few, and I can write them down:
Pray ſir do not deſire what may undo
My credit with my Lady, which truth is,
I do only value, as it may advance your ends.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: The Prince! Make ſhew as if you only
Did of me enquire for him.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: There, Lady, is Prince Clarimant, whom you
Enquire for—If he do read it here, I ſhall
Obſerve his action.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: From Clorinda this, accompanied with all misfortunes:

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Pardon the duty of a ſervant.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Stay, Lady.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I muſt receive no anſwer.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Since from her hand, however I receive it
Thus—

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Certain ſhe hath abuſed Selina:
He kift the paper, as knowing the inſide
Differs from the ſuperſcription.

sp.speaker: Clar. reads
sp.l: Of Lovers moſt injurious, of Brothers falſeſt,
Of all Mankind the worſt! Yet know I wiſh now
What before I only griev'd for, that Clarimant
Should love Clorinda, may it be to madneſs;
If leſs, only becauſe the ſenſe of torment
May be more, in which alone I can expect
A diminution of that grief, which by thy means
I ſuffer.—Thine everlaſting enemy, Clorinda.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: So long my Saint! O you Gods, do I deſerve this?
Yes, I do, for ſhe like you is juſt;
And we blaſpheme, when we in thought repine,
As not conceiving how, though certainly
We have offended; my guilt is clear,
'Tis crime enough to be the accidental cauſe
Of miſery to her.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: This ſure is real ſadneſs; Selina, I believe thee now.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Let me examine, have I not through ambition
Or hope to gain Clorinda for my ſelf,
Been aiding to my Brothers wrongs?
Sure I am guilty: I but think I did
My beſt to appeaſe my Father; yes, the Gods know,
And ſhe as being divine, may ſee my real
Love to him, not only as my brother,
But my friend; did either want, and could be
So ſupplied, how gladly would I pour this
Blood into their empty veins? and yet ſhe
Hates me thus, perhaps my brother does ſo too.
What's that? nothing: 'Tis true, if I durſt
Wholly yield my heart.
He meanly does deſerve a Lovers name,
That can know mixture in his grief, or flame.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Though you have loſt your Country for the preſent,
All your hopes daſht in the minute of your greateſt▪
Expectation; yet ſir conſider, the hand of fortune▪
That preſſes you thus low, may as ſhe turns
The wheel, raiſe you agen.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Never, oh never! 'tis not the hand of fortune
But my guilt that bears me down; Juſtice,
The juſtice of the Gods lies heavy on me,
Treaſon and diſobedience, till now I never
Found their weight.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: I know not, ſir, what you call Treaſon:
Though what you did intend, ſucceeded not,
• hold your fortune to be better now
Then in in your Fathers Court; you are ſafe in this
Country, and your own diſpoſer, neither of which
• take it was allowed you there.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Why do you injure truth, and ſeek to leſſen
My foul faults? Think not to make my grief
Diminiſh ſo; rather expreſs your friendſhip
In yielding as I do; ſo ſhall you quickly
Be inform'd that our crimes are ſo great,
No puniſhment can be too much; and I have now
No joy, but in this burden of my ſorrows.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Nor I in my particular, no grief ſo great
As in the lightneſs of my purſe.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: We have enough, theſe Jewels will
From want ſecure us; for I am reſolv'd
Never to quit this habit and condition,
Since juſtice hath impos'd it as a puniſhment
For my ambition.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.l: Make haſte, make haſte; ſure we ſhall come
Too late.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Let's leave the ſtreet.
Do you think we ſhall get neer to ſee?
Sure ſhe'll chuſe one of the ſtrange Princes.
Troth who can tell? Newſtrea affords
Handſomer men then they.
Indeed ſhe's paſt fifteen; I'll warrant ſhe has
A Sweetheart, ſome at her age have two
Or three.
Truſt me, ſhe's the wiſer to have plenty;
When age comes, they'll drop like leaves
In Autumn.

div.stage: Enter (with all the glory can be) King, Auſtella, three Princes, Lords, Ladies, Siſter, and People.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Daughter, this is the day
Wherein you have full power
To diſpoſe my Kingdom, nay more,
Your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Auſtel.
sp.l: This freedom, ſir, of choice, which cuſtom •
And your Majeſty allows, is that wherein
My bondage will conſiſt; nay, all this
Glorious troop appear to me no other
Then if they came with joy to ſee me
Put into the grave alive.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: How, daughter!

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: Many Virgins, ſir, that have been forc'd to
Marry thoſe they did not love, have rather
Choſen death as the leſs evil.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I underſtand you not; call you this force,
Where the election's abſolutely free?

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: I grant, ſir, I am free to chooſe;
But if I would not chuſe at all, does not
The ſame conſtraint ſtill reſt upon me?
Pardon, great Princes, whoſe expectation
To enjoy me and a Crown, have drawn you
From your Countries: you are all indifferent
In my eye, nor does my knowledg of your merits
Which I confeſs is great, perſwade that in
The choice of any one I ſhall be happy:
And where the wife is diſcontented, the husband ſure▪
If he have real worth, cannot be pleas'd.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: From the knowledg of the liberal power
The law allows, and the neceſſity of a ſucceſſor,
You cannot but have often thought on this dayes
Ceremony: Let not a fained modeſty,
Or be it real, prevail above your duty and your reaſon:
The ripeneſs of your years may juſtly challenge
All delight; and here a Husband, and the aſſurance
Of a Crown attend you.
If theſe do make you weep,
What can cauſe joy in woman? Since you are
My daughter, I dare not think that you have plac'd
Your love on any man you are aſhamed to name.

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: The Gods are witneſs, ſir, I never ſaw that perſon
Yet, whom I thought worthy to exchange
My heart with; but cuſtom, ſir, and you impoſe
On me the proſtitution of my love perhaps to one,
Who, wer't not for the Crown I bring,
Nay even with that addition will happily refuſe me.

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.l: Refuſe you, Madam!

sp.speaker: 2 Pr.
sp.l: He muſt not ſure be mortal,
That dare aſpire a greater happineſs.

sp.speaker: 3 Pr.
sp.l: The Gods have left heaven for mortals,
Then here there never was a greater cauſe.

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: Princes, theſe words do fitly wait upon
The action you are now engag'd in:
I do not doubt you ſhould refuſe me,
But I perhaps may chooſe one whoſe affection
Is already given; how miſerable am I then?
Since there to be refuſed, were the leſs miſchief,
For his acceptance only grants a perjur'd
And ambitious husband.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: How vain are theſe excuſes, ſince the cuſtom
And my age inforce a choice.

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: Like one condemned I beg for mercy:
Croſs not the courſe of nature; even beaſts, ſir,
Do not couple till they wooe.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Plead not the rights of nature, ſince thoſe you wrong
By thus refuſing marriage: On your poſterity
Depends the ſafety of my State, and I nor can
Nor will diſpence with what cuſtom and law
Appoint.

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: The law doubtleſs was made in favor of
The daughter, to make her happy in a free
Choice, which almoſt never is allowed to Princes;
But where like priviledges are, if not demanded,
They'r not inforct: Thoſe Countries where the
Book's allowed to ſave the forfeit life
For theft, 'tis but if askt; ſo when a Virgin
Saves a life, and gains a husband,
Yet have they in thoſe offers been refuſed,
And death embrac'd by the delinquent.
Then wonder not that I, a Princeſs, to miſs
A husband, which being inforc'd I needs muſt hate,
Do that which common perſons have perform'd.
My ſeeming diſobedience ſet againſt
Their forfeit life, Juſtice will force
Theſe Princes, and your ſacred Majeſty confeſs
That I have reaſon on my ſide, however will
And cuſtom plead for you.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Fond Auſtella, too late I fear thou wilt repent
This pride of ſoul; it is no other cauſe
Makes thee thus peeviſh: My Lords, your ear.

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: Ha! what object meets mine eyes? ſure there is
Somthing like a charm that works upon me;
Can this be natural? fie Auſtella,
Conſider theſe Princes had no power;
Let not a glance then of a ſtrangers eye
Kindle an amorous fire about thy Virgin heart:

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: The Princeſs eyes are fixt upon me,
And they are glorious ones, believe me friend.

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.l: Sir, we are all agreed; the honour to be your
Son in law, which thus we ſtill may be,
Is that we covet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Know Auſtella, ſince you refuſe the priviledges
Of your birth, and thus neglect my ſafety
And the State; that reaſon which you ſo much plead
Inveſts your ſiſter with all thoſe priviledges
Which once belong'd to you.

sp.speaker: Auſtel.
sp.l: Ah me! that I had ſooner ſe • n, or never.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.l: My ſiſter, ſir, will be better advs'id, I know.

sp.speaker: Auſtel.
sp.l: I wiſh, ſir, I had not ſo far tranſgreſt;
But do your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My pleaſure, deareſt Auſtella, is to make thee yet
What nature did ordain thee, if thou wilt chuſe
A husband.

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: I ſhall ſir, ſo you will promiſe
What the law requires upon your part.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Tis vain to make a ſecond promiſe,
With the Crown I took that Oath.

sp.speaker: Auſtel.
sp.l: Theſe Princes and all that hear me, know that I
Can chuſe but one; I hope none will repine
Since for my ſelf I chuſe.

sp.speaker: I Pr.
sp.l: None dares be ſo unjuſt to queſtion the actions
Of a Goddeſs, ſuch all true Lovers
Ever ſhould eſteem their Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Auſtel.
sp.l: Sir, in obedience to your royal will,
I am reſolved to give away my ſelf—
Stay—pauſe Auſtella—It is no leſs:
How raſh, how fatal may that bounty prove!
Shall the deceitfulleſt of all my ſenſes
Be more powerful then reaſon, duty,
Or my reſolution? No, no, my eyes,
Though as a woman I receive with joy
The beams which you convey, yet as a Princeſs
On whom depends the good of others,
Reaſon and vertue ought to ſway me more.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Is't not extremely dark upon the ſudden?

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Juſt as it was.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: O friend, I am undone for ever!

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Daughter, why do you hold us all upon the Rack
Of expectation?

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: In an affair of ſo high conſequence
Blame me not, ſir, though I adviſe. Were you to give away
A Kingdom, you would do ſo. I ſhall not only, ſir,
Do that, but likewiſe take from many,
Eſpecially theſe Princes, a Kingdom, and your Daughter;
And yet to ballance all theſe diſcontents,
Pleaſe but one perſon:

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Yes, deareſt Auſtella, your ſelf in your free choice
Of him whoe're he be.

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: You encourage me; but I, ſir, from my care
Of theſe your ſubjects for whom I am to chuſe
A King, as well as for my ſelf a husband,
Humbly deſire the Ceremonial part
Of this days cuſtom may be diſpenc'd with;
And where the manner was to praiſe the Gods
For him was choſen ſon in law, and ſo ſucceſſor
To the Crown, you now would with more reaſon
And a righter ſet devotion go to the Temple,
And invoke thoſe heavenly powers to inſpire me
With their wiſdoms in my election, which I wil make
At my return.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I know not how I, or theſe Princes, or theſe people
Can refuſe you a requeſt ſo juſt and pious,
• ending to all our goods.—Set forward to the Temple.

div.stage: Enter people paſſing over by degrees, (talking.)
div.l: Are not thoſe ſtrangers I ſent for, come?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Madam, they wait your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: Wait! why did you ſuffer it? Oh bring them in,
Yet ſtay.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: What contradiction's here?

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: How hard a part neceſſity hath thruſt upon me!
Time, till for this cauſe, I never wiſht
Thy motion ſlower; deſire them enter.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: O you Gods, was this the Lady that ſent
for us?

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: Noble ſtrangers, for ſuch your looks do promiſe,
I took the boldneſs to ſend for you to know
A truth, which from our natives, or my fathers
Subjects, 'tis not like I ſhall, ſince all are apt
Still to approve the cuſtoms of their Nation:

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Madam, when you are pleas'd to make me and my ſon
Know your demands, ſo far as our abilities inform,
Truth ſhall not ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: Say you the ſame, ſir?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: 'Twere alike vain as to diſſemble with Divinity,
Not to ſpeak truth to you.

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: What I demand, is, how you do approve
Thoſe actions of which you were late witneſſes?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I muſt eſteem that Kingdom made happy
By a cuſtom, where their proſperity
And future bliſs depends on your election,
Who have no doubt the care of heaven to govern
What you do, as well as 'tis expreſt
In the harmonious compoſing of your perſon:

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: This flattery makes me deſpair to find
That truth which I expected, and you promis'd.
Yet neceſſity does urge me to demand
A bolder queſtion: What Country do you hold
Produces the greateſt beauties?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Madam, this Kingdom, even this place contains
More then the world beſides.

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: Theſe words methinks fall from your tongue,
As if you had been taught by Love to ſpeak
Hyperboles: You have a Miſtreſs, I perceive.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Ah me!

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: Speak, have you not?

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: She loves you, on my life.

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: Oh I fear.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: What mean you ſir?
Madam, I know the Prince.

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: How ſir?

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: The Prince of Love I mean, Queen Venus Child,
Had never any power yet o're my ſon,
The war hath ever been his Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: How gladly would I flatter my deſires
With a belief of ſomething even above my hopes!
The words were ſtrangely broken and abrupt,
Is he your father, ſir?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Madam, you are the firſt that ever ſeem'd to doubt it.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs I do: withall, whate'r he ſays,
I muſt believe you are a Lover.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Madam, one truth's in both; the latter
I will ſwear, or ſeal it with my blood.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: How ſir?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: That I do love.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: How long have you done ſo?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Since the firſt minute that I ſaw the object
Of my paſſion.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I muſt increaſe your wonder at the ſtrictneſs
Of my examination: Hath many days paſt
Since your paſſion firſt took birth?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Though it may ſeem an arrogance approaching
Madneſs; yet truth, which you enjoin,
And all muſt reverence, forces me ſay
The ſun hath never ſet, ſince my affection
Riſe; a glorious paſſion ſure, if but conſider'd
From your ſelf the object.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Me! Know you to whom you ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I know you are the daughter of a King,
So to be reverenc'd: but I obey a power
That aws all ſcepters; your beauty hath erected
In my heart a greater monarchy, and that commands
Me, fear caſt by, here proſtrate at your feet,
Acknowledging my ſubjection.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Ye Gods, teach me to husband all my joys:
Although encouraged, he that dares thus profeſs
His love to me, muſt have a ſoul above the
Common rank: why do you kneel?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: You are my deſtiny, give life or death:

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: So were you mine; time bars all ceremony now,
At once receive all happineſs that I can give you.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: If this be real, I ſhall contemn addition;
Are we not in a pleaſing dream? is all this truth?

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: All certainly, if ſhe be fleſh and blood:
Ere long I hope you'll be reſolv'd.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Let none take notice of our conference,
I muſt in publique chuſe you:
If but my Father then my act approve,
None ever was ſo happy in their love.

div.head: Act. 4. Scaen 1.

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.l: SIr, we are injur'd paſt all ſufferance,
And ſhall return back to our Countries
The ſcorn of all the world.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Princes, I had no power to force the affection
Of my daughter.

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.l: Your daughter never durſt have made a choice
So much to our diſhonor, had you not been
Before acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: 2 Pr.
sp.l: Or when ſhe had, would he have given conſent,
But that it was his plot?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Let not my patient bearing of your ſlander
Make you believe I fear your angers,
Though united; yet that I may give you all
Satisfaction poſſible, the Gods be witneſs with me
I knew not her intent before, nor had I power
To hinder when the choice was made: You ſaw
Your ſelves, the people, as if inſpired to his
Advantage whom my daughter choſe, with ſtrange
Unheard of acclamation did expreſs their joy.

sp.speaker: 3 Pr.
sp.l: I wonder what they ſaw to be delighted with,
Some of our perſons are as promiſing as his.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: They ſaw one like themſelves, a common perſon choſen,
And that begot their joy and friendſhip.
Know Princes, though in honour I am bound to obſerve
Fairly my promiſe to content my ſubjects;
Not all your diſcontents, if join'd, make up one half
Of mine: but if you hold your ſelves diſgrac'd
By ſuch a Rival, am not I more, both in his preſent
Intereſt, and future expectation of my Crown?
But now to manifeſt in publike our diſcontent,
Will no ways ſuit the preſent joys attending
Hymen's rights; but you ſhall find your honours
Something righted by what I ſhall perform.
This muſick ſpeaks the Brides approach to bed,
We muſt be wanting in no outward ceremony
Cuſtom commands.—Now all retire, and leave
This happy man to enjoy a pleaſure
Which the Gods may envy; theſe Princes do, I am ſure.

div.stage: Enter Agenor, Auſtella, Siſter, Ladies, Lucidor:

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.p: This Gentleman deſerves ſo much, he is above our envy.

sp.speaker: 2 Pr.
sp.l: Some Prince diſguis'd, without all doubt.

sp.speaker: 3 Pr.
