sp.l: Moſt mighty Monarch, we ſubſcribe to your high birth,
Fate did ordain us humble vaſſals to attend your triumph.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: That this divineſt Lady judg'd me worthy,
Does raiſe me really to what your ſcorns
Do throw upon me; and were this time and place
Proper to right my ſelf, the boldeſt of you
I would make ſeal with his blood, I were in worth
His equal, however I do boaſt no title.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.l: Well ſpoke; h'as cool'd the Princes blood.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I hope, ſir, you'll remember he is my huſband,
So your ſon, in that at leaſt an equal to theſe Princes.
But happily their injuries take birth
From your expreſt diſlike: If ſo, let all
Your anger fall where it is only due, on me.
Yet Royal ſir, remember you forc'd me chuſe
A husband, and Love inſtructed 'twas only he
Could make me happy.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Why, daughter, are your joys diſturb'd?
Do you believe you and my Kingdom
Bore ſo ſmalll a value with theſe Princes,
That they could part with all their hopes
And not be moved? Their murmuring proves but
A foil to ſet you off with greater luſtre;
So raiſe your husband to an extaſie of joy,
Since he a private man poſſeſſes that which Princes
Grieve to miſs:

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.l: Madam, the King hath ſpoken what we had
Elſe alleadged in our excuſe.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: 'Tis time all ſhould retire, and leave them
To the accompliſhment of their full joys:
Remember what I injoin'd.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Age. and Auſt.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Were not my faith ſtrong in your happy
Influence, a ſadneſs now might give ſome little
Check to my full joys.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: It reaches not ſo high as ſadneſs,
Only ſome thoughts that croſt my fancie.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Madam, the Ladies of this Court are enemies
To Hymen's rights; elſe ſure they would have ſtaid
To undreſs you; all Brides that I have ſeen
Were in an inſtant ready for their bed,
So many buſie hands about them.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Perhaps our cuſtoms in that point do differ
Yet you muſt grant we are no enemies to Love.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: If ſo, you were ingrate, ſince that great Deity
In your fair ſex, hath plac'd his glory, power,
And all his ſweetneſs: which when you freely do
Diſpence to thoſe that honour you, you pay
To him the proper ſacrifice.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I do not underſtand what ſacrifice you mean.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I would inſtruct you to bed, bright Queen of Love!
All other attributes come ſhort; the zealous ardor
Of my heart commands me ſtile you ſo.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Mine to you enjoins me ſtudy how to keep
Your flame (in which I glory) pure and high;
And I believe that our imaginations
Far exceeds the touches of our ſenſe.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Be not deceived; if this, and this, beget delight,
Which, if you love, it muſt; can an increaſe
Diminiſh joy?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: No more, I muſt not truſt to demonſtration,
My faith grew by diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I find you had a woman to your Tutor;
But know, this Logick is the propereſt for Love,
Yet this is not the fitteſt School to teach it in.
To bed; and if you do not there confeſs
Our loves and joys receive increaſe,
For ever baniſh me your ſight.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Neither my love nor duty can admit that,
Since you are my husband

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Not going to bed, both point to it.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l:
You willingly miſtake; I mean, both do •
forbid
Our ſeparation.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Then ſure they do conclude the contrary:
Come deareſt, make me no longer languiſh;
You are an excellence ſo great,
You can no more receive addition by difficulty,
Then a rich pendant Diamond by a Foil.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: But yet a while I muſt be worn ſo,
You cannot have me naked.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I know you will not be ſo cruel.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: If there be any, Love be my witneſs
My heart does harbor none but to my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Take heed; the witneſs whom you call muſt
As a Judg condemn you; that Deity
And Hymen both are injured, you tempt
Their power to ſhew a judgment on you:
But they I fear are partial, making me only feel
Their rage; no, I blaſpheme, and they are juſt
In puniſhing my pride, that could believe
I merited ſo great a bliſs.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I melt at this, yielding undoes us both.
I muſt not ſtay, dear ſir good night.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: An ill and everlaſting one,
If thus you leave me.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: What ſhall I do?

div.p: Madam, the King hath ſent to ſee if yet you be at reſt.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Tell him I now am going to my chamber...
'Twas well, I had been loſt elſe.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Is't even ſo? this ſilence ſpeaks me miſerable,
From what a pitch of happineſs am I faln!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Sir, on my knees I beg a pardon for which ſoever
You condemn; never was heart then mine
More full of love and duty.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I muſt not doubt it, but yet—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Lay by all fears, and let your dreams aſſure you
Of my faith; ere long, by this, and this, reality
Shall crown your wiſhes. Pardon me modeſty,
I in theſe kiſſes only do beſtow,
Rather but pay intereſt for what I owe.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: There is diviſion in me; if ever any heart
Did at an inſtant feel both joy and ſorrow,
Sure then I do: No, it is impoſſible,
How near ſoever they appear (conſider'd) there's ſucceſſion.
Though this laſt inſtant I enjoy'd much bliſs,
Yet now I am diſpleas'd for what I miſs.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Madam, the laſt of whom I did demand,
Aſſured me in two hours we might reach the City;
The Forreſt is but narrow, as they ſay,
The way not hard to find.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: But truſt me I am weary,
I can walk no further till I reſt.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: You cannot find a fitter place then this,
My ſiſter and I will watch a diſtance from you
Whilſt you ſleep.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Indeed I find I need it; my grief and travel
Hath waſted much my ſpirits. Yet ſince for thee
Agenor, I ſhould rejoice in't, though my pains
Were greater.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: She does begin to fall aſleep,
Siſter, let's walk a little further.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: With you whither you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Hear me, thou fool, with the attention
As thou wouldſt do a God that ſhould in ſpeech
Declare his pleaſure to thee.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: What means this?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Thou know'ſt my love unto the Princeſs,
And I know thine to me hath made thee fondly
Hinder all thoſe opportunities I had to enjoy her.
But now take heed; my paſſion raiſed by
Theſe delays unto that height, it knows
No limits: If thou ſhalt ſpeak, or call
From where I bind thee by all that can be ſworn by,
Thoſe ſounds direct this dagger to thy heart.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: O you Gods, can ſo much cruelty
Dwell in your breaſt? ſure Love admits no ſuch
Companion; I was a fool that ever could
Believe it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I ſhall not greatly ſtudy to attain
Your good opinion: If by perſwaſion
I attain my wiſhes from the Princeſs.
Then this ſhall live; but if I muſt uſe force,
Then ſhe muſt dye, ſhe has a tongue.

div.stage: [Wind a Horn within: then enter Cleon.]

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: There's ſome a hunting in the Forreſt;
But by the cry, they make quite from us.

sp.speaker: Clo
sp.l: O ſave me, ſave me heaven!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Dear Madam, what affrights you?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I had a fearful dream;
My heart beats hard to find a paſſage out,
As if there were no ſafety in this miſerable
Habitation.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: What Prince that lives would not receive it
Gladly, and give you his to undergo your fears?
All I dare ſay, being your ſervant, is,
Danger ſhall pierce my heart, before it reach to you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I know it ſhall; full well thou haſt diſcharged
By thy unwearied care and pains, all that thy ſiſter
Promis'd me in thy behalf.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Madam, there's none that ſerve ſo truly
As where love is to pay the wages.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Love! what do you mean by that?
I underſtand you not.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Nor yet?—

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Ha! much leſs by this; my wonder is increas'd,
Shall I believe my eyes, or ears?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Madam, I am to claim a promiſe:
Behold the trueſt and moſt afflicted Lover
That ever beg'd relief, kneeling before you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs my promiſe was to aſſiſt you
In your love; but then, as now, moſt ignorant
Who was your Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: He is not worthy to be held a Lover,
That makes his flame glair in the publike eye,
Troubles the world with complaints: Let ſuch a one
Reap ſcron from her he loves, and a cheap pitty
From his hearers. If I muſt fall through your
Diſdain, (for know you are the Saint of my devotion)
A ſilent grave ſhall be more glorious in my eſteem,
If you in private ſhed one tear,
Then all the trophies whining Poets
Or repentant love ever adorn'd a hearſe with.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Your words alone would vaniſh into common air,
If not made ſolid by your action.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: It is ſome happineſs to gain belief,
Add but your pitty.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: My Lord, you have all that's poſſible for me to give,
Since I have but one heart.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: But if that heart be ſent you back,
You may again diſpoſe it: you ſee the Prince
Careleſs of your commands, hath raſhly through
Ambition loſt himſelf, but firſt he forfeited
His obedience to his Miſtreſs; for you confeſt this day,
You did enjoin a double temperance
Unto his love, and his ambition.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: For him, as for my ſelf, I muſt interpret
The irregularity of his actions
To grow from his unlimited affection:
And though I grieve the ſad effects, his flight
And my purſuit, I muſt not love him leſs;
The power he aimed at, was but to make himſelf
More capable to ſerve me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: The ſame end, Madam, hath directed all my actions,
Which you I hope will grant, when I have ſet
The Crown of Burgony upon your head,
Your right, this arm ſhall prove againſt the world.
Clarimant now, for the old King is dead,
Uſurps that ſcepter, the Merchant whom we
Travel'd with aſſured me:

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: All you diſcourſes have ſtrange wonders in them.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Madam, why are you ſad at that which ſhould
Rejoice you? What though no ſubject but my ſelf
Allow your claim? when I am known your ſervant
And your General, the Boy will be conten • ed
With the Principality of Cyrais,
Rather then venture loſing all.
And certain, Madam, 'tis more glorious,
And ſhould be more content to you to make a King,
Then to be made a Queen, at leaſt to wander
Seeking one to do it, who happily
Hath found another that he more eſteems.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I can no longer bear thy falſhoods,
Even thy diſguiſes do diſcover thee.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: To be the faithfulleſt of all your ſervants, Lady.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: The falſeſt that the ſun beholds; touch me not
I command thee.—Ho Selina, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: She will not anſwer you, I am engaged,
I read diſdain and anger in her eyes,
Perſwaſions will not do, I muſt try other means.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I was to blame to ſpeak ſo bitterly,
How much his looks are changed!—Selina!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: In vain you call: Madam, I ſee neither my ſufferings paſt,
Your promiſe or preſent tender of my ſervice,
Have power to gain your good opinion.
At leaſt conſider where you are, give me not cauſe
By your unkindneſs, back to reflect upon my own
Advantage, your happineſs forgot. I tender you once more
A ſervant and a husband: Acceptance
Makes me equal to a God in happineſs;
If you deny, 'tis in my power to take
A ſweet revenge.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Revenge, my Lord! I know not what you mean.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Certain you do ſuſpect, but I'll inform you fully—
Sure you forget your ſex; elſe you would rather give
Then have me force a pleaſure from you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: How, Villain!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Come Madam, you are mine; I muſt return kiſſes,
Embraces for thoſe frowns; nor art, nor force
Can free you from me.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Unhand me: Can you believe to ſcape heavens juſtice
After an act ſo foul?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: So foul! ſo fair:
Yes, often I do hope to do the ſame.
'Twas well attempted; but now it ſhall aſſiſt
The owner: Yield, or I'll pierce that
Unrelenting heart. She offers to draw his ſword.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Traitor, thou dareſt not. [She ſpits at him.]

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: 'Tis true, not kill you, had you done me wrongs •
Above what mankind ever ſuffered:
You cannot move me otherwiſe then to
Infinity of love; yield but conſent,
And be a ſharer in my joy.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Villain, think of the puniſhment that does attend thee
Rather, from the juſt Gods: yet kill me,
And I will pray to heaven for mercy on thee:

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Your beauty, and my love, both plead againſt you;
But you may think me cold to talk thus long,
We muſt remove into a thicker place.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Help, help you Gods! murder, treaſon, help!

div.l: It is impoſſible this Bore can ſcape,
Having ſo many wounds; ſure I ſhall track him
By his blood.
Within,

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Help, oh help! Traitor!

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Ha! 'tis ſure a womans voice.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Rude ſlave, how canſt thou injure ſo much ſweetneſs?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I muſt not ſpeak, but do.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: O heavens, 'tis he! guard him, you powers.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Hold, oh hold, and hear me!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: O my dear Lord, believe not ought he ſays.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Ha! what voice?
sp.stage: As Age. turns Cleo. thruſts at him.
sp.l: Villain, and Traitor both!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Oh—

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Are you not hurt?
Pardon you Powers, whom I ſo oft blaſphemed
In my deſpair, Deliverance! and by this hand!
O my joys, you grow too faſt upon me.!

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: 'Tis ſhe, the too much injured Clorinda:
Why ſhould I know her, that have ſo much
Forgot my ſelf and vertue? O my ſhame!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Why hang you down your head? theſe unbefitting clothes
Nor you nor I ſhould bluſh at,
Since love did both provide and put them on.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Your love to me?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Ha—My love to you! you cannot think
My heart is capable of other love.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I wiſh I could,
For then my falſhood had been ſo much leſs

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Dear ſir, what is it in me that offends your eys?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: This face, if it have leſs of beauty,
Yet even that loſs, ſince caus'd by ſorrow
For your misfortunes, merits from you more love.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Nor face, nor habit, deareſt Clorinda—but—

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: But what? ſtrangely unkind!

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Oh here, receive this ſword, rip up my breaſt,
And ſee what's written in my heart; there,
There thou ſhalt find the cauſe of this diſtraction:

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: No jealouſie, I hope, nor apprehenſion
That I have ſuffer'd rape, my perſon ſo
Become unworthy of your love: If either way
Defiled, I ſhould not dare to approach thus near you.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Then pardon me, divineſt Maid, this ſeeming coldneſs,
That only grows from my reſpect to injured vertue

sp.speaker: Clo:
sp.l: How ſir I • what are you guilty of?
Be it an offence committed againſt me,
Pardon your ſelf with promiſe of amends,
And I will ſeal it on this Princely hand,
That gave ſo late life to my dying honor.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: O do not touch that hand,
It was too active in your wrongs.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Ha! O my fears! I dare not queſtion more
And yet I muſt, my torment cannot well be greater •
Your hand, this hand; ſpeak, oh ſpeak!

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: This hand which you ſo often have approach •
With trembling reverence, mine; this hand
Which to your letters ſet, aſſured the free gift
Of your heart to me, hath not perſumed to give it
To another ſure.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: O yes, this hand hath inſtrumentally bequeath'd
My heart unto another, with all the ceremonial
Rights of marriage.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Married! Oh me! pain, danger, and diſgrace,
Fruits of a faithful love; behold your recompence.
O men, falſe men!—Why then theſe tears? rather revenge:
Such wrongs cry loud, and make a feeble arm
Like mine, heavens inſtrument of juſtice.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Strike where you pleaſe; but if you will be juſt,
Here, this is the ſeat of falſhood, here dwels
The traitor.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: But hear the miſerable—
Offers to kill herſelf.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: O deareſt Clorinda, add not unto my breach
Of faith, the guilt of murder; for your ſweet innocence
Could know no ſpot, but as by me infected.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Why do you make ſhews of repentance,
And yet perſiſt in injuries? You ſeem to grieve
For having made me wretched, yet force me
To continue miſerable.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: 'Tis to prevent your miſery and mine, that
I reſtrain you:
You had wont to enjoin and teach me temperance,
Remember that.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: O bid me not remember; 'tis loſs of memory
Alone can eaſe my torments; and 'tis a ſtudy,
Since you will have me live, that I muſt practiſe:

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Live, and live happily, or elſe I never can do ſo:
Live as my friend, my deareſt ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: That is a title, had nature framed me ſuch,
I had been happy in. Your brother now, or kinſman,
For I have loſt my modeſty ſo far,
Ever to take a womans habit; and whilſt I ſo
Forget my ſex, I likewiſe may forget part of my grief.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Then as my friend, I will communicate my fortunes
To you; where you will find, though nothing
Worthy of a pardon, yet ſomthing near a fair
Excuſe, it Beauty and a Crown bear eſtimation.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I know you mean your wife: O me, why did
I name her? Be not ſo weak, my reſolution:
I ſhall diſcover who I am; ſo move her hate
Or ſcorn, and then you will repent my being
Near you.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I know I never ſhall.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I am no Rival; 'tis ſin with paſſion
To affect you now, ſince lawfully anothers right.
This temperance I ſhall endeavour, however
I will do no wicked office, or ſeek to make
Appear her vertue, or her beauty leſs,
Since they are your excuſe, my ſatisfaction grows
From their exceſs.

div.head: Act. 5. Scaen. 1.
div.stage: Enter King (reading a Letter) three Princes, Lords, Auſtella.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: To force me chuſe a husband, yet bar the rights
Or marriage! But I muſt bear it, ſince my Father
And my King eſteem it fit.

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.l: What is the number of the Kings army, ſir?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Ten thouſand Horſe.

sp.speaker: 2 Pr.
sp.l: What Foot?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: None that appears, but doubtleſs they are coming
After: Princes, you may now manifeſt your love
To me and to my daughter, by raiſing forces
To aſſiſt me in this need.

sp.speaker: 3 Pr.
sp.l: You have a powerful enemy, and doubtleſs
By ſome injury highly incens'd.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Rather his power far exceeds mine;
'Tis that which makes me crave aſſiſtance from you:
My daughter, although married, is yet a Virgin;
'Tis poſſible, in time, that ſhe may prove a widow:
Theſe arguments may witneſs to you
I miſlike her choice.

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.l: Indeed ſhe looks as if ſhe were not pleas'd.

sp.speaker: 2 Pr.
sp.l: But ſhall we credit this? Lay he not with her?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Not by my honor; perhaps he never ſhall,
Though all were carried formally to pleaſe the people,
Who are enamour'd of him now, more then
My daughter is.

sp.speaker: 3 Pr.
sp.l: Sir, though I cannot think there's likelihood
That any of us ſhould ever enjoy your daughter,
Yet I will promiſe what aſſiſtance I can give.

sp.speaker: 2 Pr.
sp.l: The like do I, and for that cauſe we'll take
Our leaves.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I rather thought you would have writ for forces,
And with your perſonal aſſiſtance and advice
Help to ſecure this City.

sp.speaker: 1 Pr.
sp.l: So we ſhould loſe our ſelves to no purpoſe:
The King will ſuddenly with his Troops of horſe,
If his deſign lie hither, appear before the walls,
And cloſe us in: where if we leave you now,
We may return hereafter to your reſcue.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I dare not force, although I would perſwade you.

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.l: Lady, we wiſh much happineſs,
Till we return to ſerve you.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Now thou fond girl, thou mayſt perceive what
Thou haſt done to chuſe a husband of the common
Rank; theſe Princes might have been a bulwark
To defend againſt the powerful foe:
Whate'r they ſeem, they for thy ſake
Will not prove enemies, I fear.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: If you have done no wrong, ſir, why ſhould you
Fear? This King; whom you believe comes to
Invade, hath his dependance from the Gods,
And they can change or overturn all his deſigns▪

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thus thou didſt ever ſpeak with piety
And wiſdom, which made me in thy choice
Expect a worthy ſon in law.

div.l: But thou haſt brought ſhame and diſgrace upon me.

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: The Gods give this allay unto my joy,
Leſt in poſſeſſing you, I ſhould contemn
Their happineſs.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: My deareſt Miſtreſs, (for by that title I muſt call you)
He that does give you cauſe to weep,
Could have no other priviledge but that of
Father, to defend his heart from ſhedding
Crimſon drops: But ſince it is your will,
I muſt with patience hear yours, and my
Injuries:

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Alas, my Lord, conſider his years
Make him incapable to feel our fires
Titles and riches only pleaſe old age,
And with thoſe favors Princes often die:

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: But yet his memory, methinks, might tell
Him by looking upon you, what his deſires
Were when he married; and certain, Madam,
You have little of your mother in you,
That can obey ſo cold a precept,
Where heaven allows too, only man forbids.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: But yet that man's my Father and my King.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Remember that my intereſt in what is juſt
Exceeds both theſe: pardon the violence of
My deſires, which makes me urge this truth,
Since it ariſes from your beauties: but haply
You do repent your choice, won by your
Fathers threats or promiſes.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Although unkind, yet I muſt grant you
Not unjuſt, in this ſuſpition. Thoſe ſparks
Which quickly grow a flame, do oft
As haſtily extinguiſh; perhaps you know
This by experience, that you ſo quickly
Find my guilt, indeed before it had a being,
But what you may inſtruct me to hereafter
By your example.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: No more, fair ſoul, I only urg'd it
To obtain that which your Father bars me from,
Your bed; we muſt not differ thus, being one:
And yet ſuch gentle quarrels only divide us
So, as to behold the beauty of each others
Love, proving at laſt the proper cement
Of a true affection.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Upon a reconcilement, friends (they ſay)
Are ever kindeſt: What is't you can deny
Me then?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Nothing that's in my power to grant.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Tell me your name and country, my dear husband.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: When I do really poſſeſs that title,
By this kiſs I will.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Are we not married?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: But I am aſhamed to tell my name or quality,
And yet my wife a maid: When I do know you
Perfectly, you ſhall do me.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Now you are wanton, and I do not love you:
But where's the pretty youth you promis'd me?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: He will not tell you who I am, believe me.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Well, I'll not ask; pray you let me ſee him.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: You ſhall; he waits without,—remember
That ſhe knows not who I am.

div.l: A lovely beauty! what majeſty dwels in her eye,
How earneſtly ſhe looks upon me!
He hath not ſure betray'd me to her ſcorn.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I never ſaw ſo ſweet a Youth;
That bluſh becomes him ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Miſtreſs, I here preſent a Kinſman to you,
One that hath given ſuch teſtimonies
Of his love to me, I never ſhall forget.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: You cannot ſpeak that goodneſs, which his looks
Not promiſe; however the tye that is
Betwixt you, does oblige me.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I am betrayed, and ſhe does know me.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Are you not well ſir?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Madam, I have a grief of a ſad nature
Does oppreſs me.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Of body, or of mind?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Of both▪ and if I not expreſs it, my heart will burſt.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Looking upon your beauty, and conſidering
Your happy fortune, ay me! The very poſture
Your are now in adds to my affliction: Oh I am ſick!

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Fond man, what have I done?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Call for ſome Cordial.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: No Madam, now it needs not; the qualm begins
To paſs, perhaps you wonder, Madam,
That the love betwixt you two ſhould move
This paſſion.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Indeed I think it ſtrange, unleſs you do believe
That he hath made a choice unworthy of him.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: By all the Gods, I never ſaw a Lady yet
That I could think each way ſo excellent;
And for your love to him, no ſtory's known
That equals your affection:

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: What might the cauſe then be of your diſtemper?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I had an only ſiſter, which of all the world I loved,
• nd ſhe was ſued to by many Princes,
• ne above her far in birth, but more in merit,
• t leaſt ſhe thought ſo; ſuch power hath vows
• nd ſhews of ſervice. I oft have known them ſit
• s you do now; their hands faſt join'd, their eyes
•• xt upon either, their ſighs with all the eloquence
• f love, vowing an everlaſting conſtancie;
•• t O falſe Agenor!

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Loſt for ever!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: So was he call'd; he ſoon forſook her for another Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: 'Twas not the Prince of Burgonia, that loved your ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Yes, he that loved, and left her and his faith for ever.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: It was no wonder, he betray'd his Father;
•• t certainly ſome heavy puniſhment attends him
• hereſoe'r he is.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Perhaps he wanders up and down, to make more women
• retched.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: He's too much hated, to return back to his
Country.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Oh miſery!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Madam, I by my ſiſter was enjoin'd to ſeek him
• hrough the world.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Now ſhe diſcovers all.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Whither?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I know the ſtory; he hath told it,
• nd made me ſtrangely ſad: Truſt me, I am much
• iſpleas'd that you ſhould • ear it, for that cauſe;
• he King too I know will wonder where you are.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Let him, I needs muſt hear the reſt—
• nd did you ever find the perjur'd Prince?
—Sit down again.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Madam, I think I ſhall diſcover him.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: It were as good he did himſelf.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I heard what Country he was fled to,
Who in his company.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: What Country's made unhappy by ſo baſe
A burden? yet I have heard his perſon
Promis'd much, a handſom man.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Madam, truſt me my ſiſter had in him
All outward arguments that might produce
A paſſion; only you know there was no faith
Within; yet there was written in his face
All nobleneſs, which I dare ſay you will confeſs,
I have his picture.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Nay then—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I would not ſee a Piece, where Nature
Is ſo much diſgrac'd.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Good heavens, what have I done with it?
I lookt on it this day.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l:
O you Gods, what mercy's this ſhe ſhews •
me!

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: The King calls for you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Sure, Madam, I have left it at my chamber.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I pray you find it, I muſt ſee it.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l:
Yes Madam:—Alas, you need it no •
that have
The ſubſtance: Juſtice commands this ſhould remain with me;
True ſhadow, real miſery:

div.stage: Enter Clarimant, Clindor, Merchant, Captain, and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: If that you have inform'd me be not truth▪
Expect to ſuffer death; for on your word
I have alter'd my deſign, given the King
Time to gather men into the City; ſo as if now
He will be obſtinate, he may endure a ſiege
Some days.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: With pardon ſir, there can be no great inconveniencie
By what I did inform; the Herald you have ſent
Will ſoon return with anſwer to your demand.
But for your Brothers marriage to the Princeſs
Auſtella, there were ſo many witneſſes of that,
My teſtimony will ere long be uſeleſs.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Good heavens, can it be poſſible? My brother married,
And not unto Clorinda? Falſe Agenor!

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: She may be dead, ſir.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Ha! what ſayſt thou, Scriech-owl? That thought
Begets a fear that chils my heatt;
One way or other there is death ſure: Leave me,
All leave me!
I ſee no way for comfort; the leaſt of miſchief
Is to have a Traitor to my brother:
But rather be Agenor falſe, then ſhe be dead:
In him our ſex is only ſtain'd; in her the joy
And excellence of both is loſt for ever.
Heaven could not be ſo cruel: Vertue and all pure thoughts
Now by her happy influence are gathering ſtrength▪
I know it by my ſelf; and ſhould ſhe fall
Unripened for the grave, the Gods loſing in her
Their brighteſt image, muſt likewiſe want
Much of their adoration. If ſhe were dead,
He that ſo ſoon can love again, may, ſhe alive,
As well forget his faith: Then ſhe thus injured
May reflect a comfortable beam on me.
Vain and irrational hopes! his breach of faith
Were equal to her death; and dare I think
That ſhe can do an act imperfect,
To admit a ſecond love? But powerful time!—
No time can make me ceaſe to be his brother.
Yet even beyond all theſe, if I remain my ſelf
There is no hope, ſince her injunction was,
That I ſhould never ſee, or ſpeak to her:
And even ſince that upon miſtakes, degrees of hatred
Are increas'd; my griefs ſumm'd up, my miſeries
Are ſuch, as they do leave no comfort
But in their abundance, whoſe weight muſt quickly
Preſs me to the grave.
Theſe miracles do only grow from love,
That grief in their exceſs ſhould comforts prove.

div.l: Avarice, thou bane of man, that ſteal'ſt into
Our ſouls with promiſes of happineſs,
But ever pay'ſt us with diſturbance!
The ſame in its effect is Pride, that ſets
A gloſs upon our ſelves and actions,
And throws contempt on others more deſerving.
Covetous to keep a treaſure, made me detain
What I unjuſtly ſtood poſſeſt of:
Ambition made me uſe with ſcorn and injury
My daughters husband, even whilſt he was in birth,
Although unknown, that which I wiſht, a Prince;
And now when I do know his blood and value,
Fear of this ſtorm that hovers o're my head
Muſt force me to deliver him up to his brother,
Although he be in birth that brothers King.
O you juſt Powers! thus do you make the
Breaches of your laws for our own covetous
And ambitious ends, the proper inſtruments
To execute your wrath by. Moſt noble Prince,
The injuries that I have done to you and Juſtice,
•• mbles me thus low upon my knees
• o beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Ay me! This ſcorn exceeds all former wrongs:

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Sir, what you do intend by this, I know not;
• ut well I know the poſture cannot ſuit you:
• ou are my Father, ſir, 'tis not your cruelty
Or injuſtice ſhall make me fail in duty;
• he ſenſe of my firſt breach that way
• till dwells within me: Riſe ſir, I do beſeech you.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I would not till you pardon.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Alas ſir, why do you mock us thus?
For all our injuries muſt be the ſame,
Howe'r you ſtrive for to divide us:

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: No, Auſtella, theſe tears be witneſs of
My real ſorrow: The Gods inſpired thee
When thou choſe this worthy Prince.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: How ſir?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: But found me too unworthy of a beam of light
Till now; that knowledg proves my greateſt curſe,
Since our misfortunes are remedileſs:

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: You have too ſoon, ſir, rob'd me of the joy
To know he is a Prince, by this expreſſion
Of your fears for ſomething that's to come;
But ſir, in this you were indeed the faulty perſon.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I fear I ſhall be found ſuch.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Could you conceal ſuch joys from me?
But I muſt pardon you all faults,
You are a Prince, I dare not chide you.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Upon your hand let me expreſs my thanks:
But will you freely pardon for what I have
Conceal'd?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Gladly I do.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: You will not ſure.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Be your doubts clear's by this.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Daughter, you grant what you ſhould beg:
Let that inform you who your husband is, [A Letter]
My injuries to him, and our misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Still your concluſions fright me: Good ſir read it your ſelf,
Or rather in ſome gentler circumſtantial way
Inform what it expreſſes.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Firſt know, this paper does contain the Kings
Demands, who with his Army hath now inclos'd
The City, which how we can deny or grant—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Pray read ſir.

sp.speaker: K. reads.
sp.l: Your own injuſtice hath drawn me into your Country;
Yet I take ſo kindly the alliance you have contracted
With my brother Agenor—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Agenor!

sp.speaker: K. reads.
sp.l: That if you will deliver up the Iſle of
Ceris belonging
To my Crown, and my Brother to me alive, I will quit
Your Country, well ſatisfied with my charge; but if in
Any part of this you fail of an exact performance,
To morrow I hope to make my own conditions.
Be adviſed by him, who appearing your worſt enemy,
May in this councel prove your greateſt friend—
Clarimant:

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Oh Agenor!

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Now can you pardon?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Now can I die; O fate, where have you plac'd my love?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Do you repent? I ne'r was falſe to you,
Nor ever can be.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Let not my Father hear; I muſt forgive,
You are my husband:

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I cannot blame your ſorrow; your fortune does command
A plenteous ſhowre, in which I willingly could bear a part,
If reaſon did not tell me councel and advice
Better becomes my quality: I mean not councel
From my ſelf to you, but that we all adviſe
Since equally concern'd, what's to be done.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Methinks juſtice and reaſon both chalkt out the way
Of your proceeding.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: As how, dear ſon?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Too late, ſir, from your heart you yield that attribute.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Auſtella, thy reproof is juſt.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: With pardon, ſir, it is not; all the fault is mine,
And juſtice bids me bear the puniſhment.
Yield ſir to all my brother Clarimant deſires,
Since by his ſpeedy unexpected coming
Your forces nor ſupplies from others can be uſeful.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: The treaſure and the Iſle moſt willingly I will ſurrender,
(Would it pleas'd heaven we all were there!
Gainſt that no forces could prevail.)
But to deliver you, that by your death
He may ſecure himſelf, firſt let deſtruction
Seiſe on me, already ripen'd for the grave.
My brother, ſir, did ever love me,
Perhaps ſo as his brother; but now you are
His King in juſtice, but ſelf-reſpects will point you
Out the object of his fear, not of his reverence.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: He cannot be ſo impious to kill me.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: You ſhall not truſt him.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Conſider then what hazard all muſt run,
The lives of thouſands, a Kingdoms utter ruine.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Alas, 'tis true:

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: You may periſh too, but in my hazard all
Are ſafe; 'twere madneſs to diſpute it further.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: What ſafety, and you loſt?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: No loſs, if you conſider truly what I merit:
You are a Virgin yet; I freely give you back
Your vows; juſtly you might revoke them
As not intended to a perjured perſon,
Such you now find I was.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: But ſuch I hope you are not now to me:

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Think me ſuch if I miſcarry,
'Twill make your grief the leſs.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: But my guilt more in that ſuſpition:
Did I not think you loved me, yet duty
Does command me ſhare in all that you can ſuffer.
But confident your heart is here, till death,
Not then, I muſt not leave you.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: The glory of the action makes you too partial
To your ſelves; we muſt diſpute this further
With my Councel.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: In vain you will diſpute, if you intend to part
What heaven hath join'd, which rules both power
and art.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Well, I perceive that we ſhall loſe a noble Prince:
How happy had we been in his ſucceſſion!

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Without all doubt the King his brother
Will ſoon by police or force deſtroy him;
Poſſeſſion of a Crown will kill all natural
Reſpects of blood.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: But why then ſhould we not reſiſt?
Juſtice hath a ſtrong arm.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Yet in apparent dangers, fear ſtill overcomes
Our faith and courage; but here's impoſſibility:
Our City, though great and populous, hath but poor walls:
The Kings army, now his Footmen likewiſe
Are come up, are not without a miracle
To be reſiſted.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: But was't not moſt diſhonorable to invade us
Without proclaiming war?

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: To ſpeak to you the truth, it was but juſtice:
Did not our King detain a maſs of treaſure
To which he had no right?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: 'Tis true,—but—

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: But what? Come, come, all unjuſt actions
However they ſeem profitable for the preſent,
Involve a curſe within them; which when we find,
We muſt not lay the blame on others:
The beſt way to appeaſe the Gods
When we have done amiſs, is to confeſs;
Then mercy follows, or our blows wound leſs.

sp.speaker: 1 So.
sp.l: Think you they will ſurrender the treaſure,
And yield Agenor to our King, or bide the brunt
Of war?

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: I'll tell thee what I fear, and what I wiſh;
And if thou doeſt not ſo, thou art an aſs.

sp.speaker: 1 So.
sp.l: Well, ſpeak:

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: I fear they will ſurrender, I wiſh they would not:
O Lads, might we but come to one aſſault,
We ſhould be Lords, we that do venture blows;
Where in theſe Treaties we are ſure to have
The worſt on't: If peace be the concluſion,
Would I had been imployed upon the Treaty.

sp.speaker: 1 So.
sp.l: Why, what wouldſt thou have done?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: Heard no reaſon, nor offer'd any: the firſt condition
Should have been, that all the handſom young
Women and maids in the City ſhould have come
Stark naked to have known our pleaſure;
Then the rich men with their jewels and bags
Of mony; then the King with a rope about his neck.

sp.speaker: 1 So.
sp.l: Stay there.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: That may be your period, 'tis not mine
Then for the Prince Agenor—
What of him?

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Nothing but good, I love him well,
He was a ſtirring youth, and bountiful,
But yet not like our King: were the people not
So baſe, he ſhould (might I adviſe) be left Viceroy
To govern, and I to govern him.

sp.speaker: 1 So.
sp.l: In my conſcience ſhould our King ſhew him that favour,

Thou would'ſt perſwade him to rebell againſt hi •
brother.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: By this light I think I ſhould, I love to be in action ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: 1 So.
sp.l: That love may chance to bring you to a preferment
You have courted long, and in my conſcience well deſerv'd:
Others that were leſs worthy when Agenor fled,
I ſaw advanc'd.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: I underſtand you now, you are a bitter Raſcal;
And here's my hand, if ere there be more broils,
For this thy kind remembrance I'll cut thy throat.

sp.speaker: 1 So.
sp.l: I thank you ſir, I'll look for't.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: See all things order'd as I gave command:
I long to ſee the perjur'd Traitor,
That I may do a juſtice
To my Fathers ghoſt, and injur'd Miſtreſs.

div.l: The King, his daughter Auſtella are coming,
With your brother Prince Agenor.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Traitor Agenor! It ſeems they mean
To bear him company in death; Attend them in—
Do all juſt as I did direct.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Brother, you ſee the advantage of your power
Forces this viſit.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: 'Twill prove to you a ſad one: Seiſe the Rebel.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: In the dead and living Kings names we do arreſt you.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: And I in my own name, your King
In juſtice, command you hold▪

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: O ſir!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Riſe Madam; your interceſtion muſt not interpoſe
In this, alone of power to ſave the lives
Of many Princes.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Juſt heaven, he's taken!
This was the miſchief I fear'd.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: No Madam; juſtice alone commands me to ſurrender
This where it is due.

div.stage: The Captains put the Crown on Agenor's head.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Long live Agenor,
King of Burgonia.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: This is not real, ſure.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: What mockery is this?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O brother, the Crowns of Princes
Are things to which we owe a reverence,
Not to be us'd in ſport; what are their
Sacred perſons then?

sp.speaker: Au:
sp.l: Let me fall down and worſhip
What a ſtrange God-like race of men
Theſe pair of Brothers are!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Madam, I muſt not ſuffer that which I am
Infinitely pleas'd with, ſince it expreſſes
Your exceſs of love unto my brother.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I am confounded with ſuch unexpected
Courteſie, that I am loſt in all acknowledgment
That may expreſs the power that you
Muſt ever hold upon me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: What I have done, juſtice commanded from me
If not, my love hath ſtill been ſuch to you
My brother, that had I been the Monarch
Of the earth, your power ſhould have been equal.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: This action is ſo noble, that it does make
Us more your ſervants then all force could effect,
You have ſubdued our minds.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You ſet ſo high a price on Juſtice,
That you confirm my reſolution;
Though from the actions I muſt do,
Will ſeemingly ariſe my proper ſmart.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Command our fortunes, and our lives.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The hazard of your life is that I muſt demand▪

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: As how to be imployed?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: In taking mine.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Yours! what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: To kill you, if you cannot me:
I muſt not live, knowing whom you have injured.
And not endeavor to revenge.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: You cannot be in earneſt ſure;
If ſo, look here.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Could you behold the Image in my heart,
In the true ſplendor that it wears;
You would not bid me view another object,
Excellent I confeſs, if not compared.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Brother, if you thus preſs me,
I ſhall forget all you have done;
Since there's no benefit ſo great, but may be
Cancell'd by the doer.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I wiſh what I have done, had in it all
That could oblige, that I did love you more,
If Poſſible, that you were nearer to me
Then a brother, ſince all degrees of intereſt
Serve but like ſteps to raiſe the glory of my love
And juſtice higher.—
Chuſe which you pleaſe—
This; the time and place?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Be witneſs heaven, which what unwillingneſs:
Yet ſince you, Honour and love engage me:
I'll offer to my Goddeſs (left ſhe ſuſpect my zeal)
A much loved Brothers blood.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: O Soldiers! will you ſuffer thus the worlds Glories
To ecclipſe themſelves?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Madam, in vain you urge;
I did before engage them by an oath,
Whatever I commanded, to obey me.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Cannot my prayers or tears? O dear my Lord!
Your brother's young, and by the glory
Of his paſſion, hath loſt much of his reaſon:
Conſider what a miſchief even victory
Muſt prove to either:

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Neceſſity enforces me to accept the combat.
All circumſtance conſider'd, how more then baſe,
Ingrate, muſt I appear? how dull a ſenſe
Shall I expreſs of your perfections,
To hear another magnified above you?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: If I with that diſpence, who can complain?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Such diſpenſations makes your value more,
And ſo adds to the juſtice of my cauſe.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: To you I turn then: Will you needs end
An action ſo gloriouſly begun, in blood?
A brothers murder, or your own? What you have done,
Shewed you a Demy-god, ecclipſing all
That ſtory hath recorded: but ſuch an end
As you deſign, will caſt you from the height
Of all your glory, and leave you to poſterity
A hated name.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: If ſo, yet ſtill I ſtand engaged: Love, and my fate
Appoint this way to ſhew the ardure of my flame,
Which by no common action could be witneſs'd.
To that you urge, add this: I know I am
Inferior to my brother in skill and ſtrength;
Yet what to others have been bars in combats,
To me prove arguments impulſive.
In ſhort, the Deity that I adore's prophan'd,
Contempt and ſcorn thrown on her:
If by a feeble arm ſhe right herſelf,
It more does manifeſt her power;
However I ſhall fall, ſince hers, a happy
Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Hold! rather a wretch prophane, and moſt
Injurious to that Deity, to whom thy falſe
And counterfeit devotion ſeems directed.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O you Gods! Grant thy ſelf mad, rather
Prove ſuch; or by what's deareſt to me,
I'll pierce thy heart.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Do ſo.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I ſhall be known.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Have I not ſeen a face reſembling this?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Does the guilt with which I juſtly tax you,
Abate your rage? let Gods and men hear what
I urge, nay, your own conſcience be a Judge;
And if I then be found injurious, kill me;
No hand is fitter to give concluſion
To my miſery.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: How am I loſt! this is no time for talk:
Soldiers, remove him.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Hear me!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: By what you hold the deareſt, I conjure you
Hear me! Deny that, and ſo make good
All I accuſe you of.—This is ſome hope
He knows me not.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: If I conſent, by the ſame power
You may command me ceaſe the combat.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I ſwear the contrary.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Be brief then; and for this interruption,
Soldiers, I conjure you by your oath
To kill him when the combat's ended,
My innocence acquits you from his blood.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Anſwer me then, you that pretend your ſelf
So great a Votary to Love, and friend to
Juſtice: Is't lawful for any who is not
A Prieſt, to offer ſacrifice?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: None may.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: What warrant for your preſent action then,
To ſacrifice your brother, or your ſelf?
If you alleadg, your love muſt know
No limits, are you not then prophane?
But grant your youth and folly this;
That love that's ſo irregular, pays a devotion
Sure; but where? Not to a Miſtreſs, but vain-glory
And ſelf-conceit. Your Miſtreſs, ſure hath no leſs
Power with you, you think, then that of Kings
Over their ſubjects: Who dare make war
Without commiſſion from his Prince?
You cannot boaſt one from your Miſtreſs;
When if ſhe be that excellence which you pretend,
'Tis not unlike ſhe wiſhes well to him
Whom you would puniſh as her enemy:
Sure ſhe hath cauſe to hate you for preſumption,
Hypocriſe and treaſon: All which, if well conſider'd
By an impartial Judge, appear to be the
Groundwork of your preſent action.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: 'Tis ſhe; for who could elſe ſo powerfully
Condemn me?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: What I have ſpoke, is in my own defence,
Who am • ill now unknown, a brother
To the injured perſon; and had there been
A wrong reſented by thoſe that were concern'd,
So far as blood might expiate, my ſword
Of yours in juſtice had precedence.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: She would not have me know her: I muſt confeſs
Your former words have made ſo deep impreſſion
In me, by ſometime touching upon truth,
That here the difference with my brother ends.
But what you laſt urg'd concerning the
Precedence of a Brothers ſword, I am ſo far
From granting, that if my reaſon
Cannot alter your opinion, my ſword ſhall force you
To deny it, when time doth better fit.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Moſt gladly.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: In how poor things does ſhe and Fortune
Give me power to ſerver her!

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Moſt excellent Prince! how much we all do owe
You for our preſent happineſs!

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: For me, I hold my Crown, my life, nay more,
Poſſeſſion of my fair Auſtella.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Since by the mercy of the Gods, the ſtorm
That hung over our heads threatning blood
And ruine, is thus removed; let us with joyful
Hearts haſte to the Temple, and there by
Hecatombs of ſacrifice expreſs our thanks:

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Whilſt I
That cauſe this joy, prepare to die:

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O thou great Deity, obſerve her ſcorn!
What I have done, was fore-deſign'd by thee:
Revenge! but let her puniſhment prove love of me.

div.head: Epilogue, to the King.
div.l: IF what hath been preſented to your ſenſe
You do approve, thank your own influence;
Which moving in the ſtory that you told,
Infus'd new heat into a brain grown cold.
Thus far our hopes: But now juſt fears begin,
For much that is left out, for more brought in;
But ſince all change was to the better meant,
Although we fail, yet pardon for th' intent.
Such ſweet indulgence from good natures fall,
But the ſtrict Critick will for cenſure call.
We would pleaſe both; and ſince we want the art, [Kneels]
Sir, ſtay the ſentence till the ſecond Part:
Such favour oft your piety lets fall
Vpon delinquents no leſs criminal.
Stay! even in policie your grant is fit;
Hope quickens, what deſpair makes dull, the wit:
Nay, could our Author ſome new arts diſplay,
Yet this condemn'd, you'l ſlight the ſecond Play.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: HIgh labour'd lines you may expect from thoſe,
Whoſe pleaſure is their ſtudies: Moſt here knows
This Author hunts, and hawks, and feeds his Deer,
Not ſome, but moſt fair days throughout the yeer.
Such rude dull heavy Scenes expect you then,
As after ſuppers vapours from his pen.
Would you not ask, Why then does he write Plays,
Since now great Wits ſtrive for Dramatick bays?
Pardon what's paſt: That way now counted wit,
Although enjoin'd, he'l deal no more in it:
Since dying to the Stage, his laſt requeſt
Is, that you would not like the worſt Scenes beſt.
If this deſire injurious ſeem to ſome,
I wonder not: Divers to Plays do come,
Not to be pleas'd, unleſs the Play be bad;
So what th' ingenious like, doth make them ſad:
We tax not here their judgment or their wit,
But that ſo much ill nature's join'd with it.
Others there be, which like the Auſtrian race,
Wits empire tyes alone to thoſe they grace:
Nay, ſo opinion'd of themſelves they be,
They'l praiſe things moſt abſurd; and when they ſee
Thoſe whoſe ſimplicity admires their wit,
To do the ſame, they laugh at them and it.
'Tis not theſe Bugbears that do haunt the Stage,
Should fright an Author; ſince 'tis plain, this Age
Hath more clear Judgments then was ever known:
But moſt Apollo's beams break from the throne,
And with a double ſweetneſs doth invite
All that have gifts in Verſe or Proſe, to write.
Which he would ſtill, but that his period's paſt;
For ſure you'l find this Play worſe then the laſt.

div.head: THE Paſsionate Lover, SECOND PART. Act. 1. Scaen. 1.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: MY Lord, be confident, thus chang'd, there's none can know you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: But dare I hope thou haſt forgiven me?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: The mercy that you ſhewed in unbinding me,
May well aſſure you; nor am I ignorant
How far our paſſions may tranſport, aided by hope
To attain our ends.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: But now the current of my love runs in the proper
Channel, and ſhall ever center here, a tribute juſtly due
Unto the ocean of thy love: Why did I fondly dream
There was a happineſs exceeding this?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Your Kindneſs was ſo great, ſo unexpected,
That I am now more yours then ever: I never muſt
Forget the pains you took in coming to unbind me,
Creeping upon your hands, all ſmear'd in blood,
'Twas well you ſcap'd with life.

sp.speaker: Cle. aſide.
sp.l: Thanks to my privy coat; had I expir'd
In ſuch a pious action, yet ſo I ſcarcely had
Deſerv'd forgivenes, much leſs this ſweet continuance
Of your love, ſure to be valued far above Clorinda's hate,
Whoſe intereſt to a Crown made her
In my ambitious eye appear more beautiful;
But now, reaſon commands her yield to thee
Precedence in my heart.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: How eaſily we give belief to what we wiſh!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Though the Gods know how all my love is cacell'd,
Juſtly turn'd hate to her; yet love and gratitude to thee
Commands me to attempt the Crown of Burgonia,
Offer'd into my hands.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: As how offer'd?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I count it offer'd, when it appears in reaſon
Within the reach of our endeavours: Of ours, I ſay,
Mark me, my Queen, in thee it lies to rule me
And a ſcepter.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: It is fit the honor of your love ſhould render me
Conformable to your deſires: Name me the way
To this your happineſs, ſo mine.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: The ſeeming pious Druid here our Hoſt,
I have diſcover'd to have been a Mountebank
Phyſitian; yet now diſguis'd, eſteem'd by all
This Country a holy and moſt ſacred perſon,
With whom the Gods are converſant here in this ſolitary
Melancholy Grove. By him with gold corrupted,
I doubt not to effect revenge againſt Agenor
For this wound moſt baſely given me:
Diſpatch his brother Clarimant; nay even Clorinda
(As witneſs of my love to thee) ſhall likewiſe bleed.
This done, and this is in thy power to effect,
Is not the Kingdom of Burgonia mine
By right of blood?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: 'Tis certain, they remov'd, you are the next.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Conſider then, my dear Selina, what 'tis to be a Queen.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: A Queen!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Take but theſe thoughts into thy ſoul,
And there's no action difficult or dangerous:
But we have only ſhadows to encounter with,
The iſſue real pleaſures.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I muſt yield; diſpoſe me, ſir, which way you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: That reſolution does already crown thee.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I would not have you think it is my ambition,
But my love engages me; but yet I fear.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: What can you doubt?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Swear ſir by the immortal Gods,
To make me privy to all your actions;
And when you have attain'd the Crown, to marry me,
So to remove ſome jealouſies.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I do by all that's ſacred; nothing but death
Shall part us; this kiſs be farther witneſs—

div.l: O ſir, you are welcome! what news?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: I have no leiſure now to tell you:
I muſt diſguiſe to entertain ſome curious
And devout people.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: He every day goes to the City
In a ſeveral ſhape, ſo to enable himſelf
To appear more knowing here: I wonder much
None of the Court are ſo zealous to viſit him,
At leaſt to know their fortunes,
For he delivers oracles as from the Gods.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: No doubt there are; but now the preſent time
Affords ſo much diſcourſe of other peoples
Fortunes, that they neglect the knowledg
Of their own.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: To know the fate of others,
Does often give a light to ours:
At leaſt let us be diligent, whoſe induſtry
Can only make us happy: Perform but carefully
That which I ſhall impart,
And thou ſhalt have a Crown to crown thy art.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Moſt noble Prince! though you may well believe
The forces you have brought unto my aid
I ſhall not uſe, yet I muſt ever be ambitious
To requite that love which caus'd your diligence;
Nay, I ſhall think my happineſs defective,
Although great, till fortune point ſome way
Wherein I may expreſs my gratitude to you.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Moſt royal Sir! fortune hath been to me
Auſpicious, more then had I proved Auſtela's
Choice; and this expreſſion you have made,
Imboldens me to let you know wherein.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Sir, I beſeech you name it.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Know ſir, not my ambition to enjoy your Kingdom,
Could ſo far blind my judgment, but that I ever
Found your younger daughter Olinda, in herſelf,
The more deſerving love, eſpecially from me.
I would not, ſir, ſay more, leſt I ſhould ſeem
To boaſt a happineſs which merit never can attain
But by infinity of ſervice, and much ſuffering.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Indeed I did obſerve, whilſt you were in my Court,
You much more did converſe with her then with Auſtela,
Who ever was reſerved. If Olinda's affability
Have gain'd your good opinion, your courtſhip hers,
It is a happineſs beyond which I dare not expect.
If it be leſs then this, and that by the freedom
Of her humor you believe your intereſt greater
Then indeed it is; yet there will only be
Better occaſion for my love to ſhew it ſelf.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: My actions ſhall ever witneſs for me
How I prize your royal favour.
Did you not lately murmure againſt peace,
Cryed up war as the only bleſſing?

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Yes, I did ſo.
I ſcarce remember your ſword did ever purchaſe
Such gay Capariſons.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: I ſee thou art a very ſimple Fellow:
This is the harveſt of the war; the King
Whom we did terrifie, made Preſents unto us
Commanders. If thou canſt ſhew me where Soldiers
Are made much of in cold blood, then I will
Magnifie thy mouldy miſtreſs, Peace:
Till then, Bellona, thou art my Patroneſs.
Thou talkeſt as if thou hadſt done ſome mighty
Matters; and yet I fear thou art a Coward.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: I love you, ſir, too well to let you ſuffer
Such a grief as fear, for me: Draw.
Draw! are you mad? or is your wit ſo great To ſpoil
Your memory? were not two ſhot to death that were
Seen fighting?

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Very pretty, you grow valiant to abuſe me,
Becauſe their valor found a puniſhment.
The Prince! Juſtice, ſir, I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: For what, or againſt whom?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.p: He told me, ſir, he thought I was a Coward.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Perhaps you have given him cauſe to think ſo.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.p: Better and better! But ſir, may men ſpeak all they think?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Why not? I do ſo, and never will again Diſſemble.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.p: But may I, ſir?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Yes, ſo it be not blaſphemy or treaſon.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.p: How, ſir, do you diſtinguiſh treaſon?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Look what the Law ſays,

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.p: Pox on the Law!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: I cry your Highneſs mercy; I had forgot the Law was ſo
Near kin to you: This ſcurvy fellow has made me mad.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You would not live without law.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: No, I beſeech your Highneſs grant me the Law.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Moſt willingly.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: The law of Arms, ſir, and let him prove me a Coward
Before your Highneſs, and ſee how I will defend my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I know not how in juſtice I can pardon this Unleſs I do pronounce you mad.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.p: I do beſeech your Highneſs do ſo.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Sure you are mad.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Then I may kill this Raſcal, and your law cannot
• ang me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Bind him, to prevent miſchief.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Any thing to ſave my honor; let me not have my hands
• oſe; wear a ſword, and be call'd Coward!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: He did but think ſo.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Let him not think aloud then in my hearing.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Come, I will end the difference; I do pronounce
• ou are no Coward, and him a fool for thinking ſo.
• e friends.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Not with a fool; you ſhall excuſe me ſir▪

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Be gone, and leave me.
Why do I give this intermiſſion to my ſorrows?
• lorinda's Pleas'd I ſhould be miſerable:
•• nce in no other way, in that I will content her.
• ut this obedience yields a ſatisfaction;
• nd ſatisfaction fits not perfect ſufferings▪
Which ſhe the perfecteſt of creatures feels.
• can no more admit to be leſs miſerable
• hen my Miſtreſs, then I could be content to be
More happy; is there no way to change my fate
With hers? O no, her torment riſes from the
• alſhood of her Lover, where ſhe had plac'd her joys:
Mine, in the not attaining of a Love
Where I dare not pretend to merit:
• am a happy man, if by compariſon I judge:

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Still alone, dear brother!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Moſt noble ſir, why do you thus retire your ſelf
From thoſe who know no ſatisfaction
Greater then your company? I muſt pretend
The intereſt of a ſiſter now; you ſhall not
Hide your paſſion, nor the cauſe from me,
I know 'tis Love.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Madam, it is confeſt: But ſince deſpair
Is, and muſt ever be the only iſſue of my love,
I would not have thoſe I eſteem
Engaged with me in miſery.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Can you be ſo unjuſt to your own merits
To deſpair?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: So juſt to her perfections.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: If not a Judge of this, at leaſt make me
Your Advocate: yet all my eloquence
Will reſt in ſhewing her the happineſs
That ſhe refuſes.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Madam, ſhe is not capable of any increaſe,
She's dead to me and all mankind.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: How mean you? by a figure, or dead indeed?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I'll take her off from this diſcourſe,
Leſt ſhe diſcover Clorinda in diſguiſe.
Dear Auſtella, in vain you ſtrive to comfort him,
That can know none, his Miſtreſs dead.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Rather in vain I ſtrive to know what both
Reſolve to hide from me: It was not curioſity, ſir▪
But a deſire to ſerve you: That belief
Will ſpeak my pardon.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I fear ſhe is diſpleas'd.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Reaſon hath too much power over her fou •
To be diſpleas'd without a cauſe: I hold her
Every way ſo perfect, that I durſt make
A full diſcovery, crave her aſſiſtance;
But then Clorinda would more juſtly hate.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: O brother, ſpeak no more of hate; it is impoſſible,
If ever ſhe did love me. You have my Intruſt,
But much more prevailing muſt your unequal'd merit
Prove.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Merit! dear brother, it is impoſſible:
Since what I have done, or ſhall ever do,
Grows from her influence upon me.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I ſee that I am yet to learn what it is
To be a perfect Lover.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Rather you have not practis'd what you know.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Brother, I muſt confeſs it is my ſhame,
Though not my grief, ſince my inconſtancie
Hath made me but more happy.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Frown not: I mean more happy,
As my inconſtancie leaves you Clorinda free;
And if ſhe prove averſe to your deſires,
Her conſtancie to me admits of a juſt cenſure,
Not applauſe.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: If you believe you have a power in her
After your breach of faith, ſuch as may aid me
In my love; ſhe is not that perfection
That I adore, and by ſuch yielding
Could not make me happy.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Then you propoſe a love without a poſſibility
Of ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Yes, if it ſuit not with her excellence:
The Gods ſometimes appoint us ſuch ſad fates,
That 'tis our duty to purſue and glory in our miſery.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I ſee a miracle muſt make you happy:
Be not diſpleas'd that I invoke the Deity
In your behalf; and Brother, know that thoſe
Who would be held the moſt devout,
Eſteem things juſt and worthy, becauſe they do
Proceed from a divine power; not that they are
Agreeing to our faith, or underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Brother, what you would undertake in my behalf
Becomes your love to offer, but not mine to accept.
A perſon truly humbled by ſenſe of his unworthineſs,
Sure dares not hope: And to admit an Advocate,
Suppoſes that; nay merit in himſelf, or in the
Interceſſor; or which is worſe, an eaſineſs
To be overcome with words. Any of this
Is ſuch impiety my love cannot be guilty of:
Her being his perfection, all things great or good,
Clorinda nam'd, in that is underſtood.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Dear Lady, let me know how I have loſt
Your favour.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Firſt let me know why you believe you
Ever had it?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: When I was here a ſuitor to your ſiſter,
You did not then look with ſuch ſcorn upon me.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Be ſo again to any other, and I will give you cauſe
To think me every whit as kind.
Here you diſcourſe of Love; expreſs a ſenſe
Of what you do proſeſs to ſuffer by way of
Martyrdom, perhaps accompanied with a ſad ſigh
Or two.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: And can you yet be crueller? when you your ſelf
Have caus'd a nobler paſſion then what I made
But ſhew of to Auſtela.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: It ſeems then you can counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs; but yet—

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Nay ſpare excuſes: As I live, I like you the better
For it; and if you love me now, know this to comfort you,
We only can agree in being diſſemblers.

div.stage: Enter Clorinda and Selina, (as in diſcourſe.)

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: Moſt noble ſir! methinks my Genius
Should have inform'd me the happineſs of your approach;
And yet 'tis fit I leave you now,
But there does ſtay my beſt of wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: She had like to have ſaid, her heart:
Alas poor Lady, how love does fool thee!

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: It muſt be ſo; this ſtranger is the cauſe
Of her neglect to me: With what unwillingneſs
She parted from him! I will not, cannot ſuffer
This ſecond affront; I ſhall become the ſcorn
Of all men.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: What means this!
But why, Selina, when I call'd,
Came you not to help me?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Alas, Madam, I was faſt.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Could you ſo quickly be ſo ſound aſleep?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Weary with travel. But, Madam, what ſaid Agenor,
(The King I now muſt call him) when he perceived
It was Lord Cleon, his truſted friend,
That he had ſlain?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: He does not know it yet, nor ever ſhall:
For ſince his paſſion to me procured his death,
His faults be buried with him: Beſides, I know
It would have been no little torment to Agenor
To find ſuch falſhood.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Is it poſſible that you can yet conſider him,
Otherwiſe then to revenge his falſhood?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: If thou hadſt ever truly loved,
Thou couldſt not ask me ſuch a queſtion: Clarimant!
I muſt not ſtay.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Sir, though you have hitherto found means to avoid me,
Yet having now the opportunity,
I needs muſt preſs you to a ſhort diſcourſe,
And ſuch a one as will require the abſence
Of your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I muſt obey neceſſity: Leave me.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Is it poſſible he does not know her?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I ſee you wear a ſword, and make no queſtion
But you know, or think you do, how to maintain
With it the aſſertions of your tongue.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: In what?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Is it poſſible that you can ask? yet ſince I muſt,
I wil refreſh your memory, and whet my own revenge
By repetition. You, as a brother, did pretend
You had more intereſt to right Clorinda's wrongs,
Then I her ſervant.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: And proved it, did I not?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: In part the oratory of your tongue prevail'd,
And I condemn'd my ſelf; but honor forc'd me
Make appeal unto my ſword, and there you muſt
Orecom me too, before I quit ſo dear a cauſe.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Truth told me then, and bids me ſtill maintain
That I am moſt concern'd in what Clorinda ſuffers:

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Your reſolution pleaſes above expreſſion:
Which forces me an enemy to beg the favour
To kiſs that hand, though it may prove to me
An inſtrument of death.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Keep off; I dare not truſt a reconciled foe,
Much leſs an enemy profeſt. Imploy your ſword,
Whoſe force I fear leſs then the impoiſon'd flattery
Of your tongue.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Then guard your ſelf, your breaſt lies open.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: You ſhall not find it ſo, if you dare ſtrike.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Alas it is too true; you have a guard which I
Can never force; and ſince inviſible, it is fit I yield;
Here to confeſs my ſelf orecome, is to triumph.
But if you hold your victory your ſhame, which much I fear,
Then purge that ſtain with my heart-blood,
A ſacrifice moſt juſtly due to your diſdain.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: A Cowards blood can have no vertue in it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Imploy your ſword then, and nobly take revenge
Upon your enemy: I ſwear, that act
Will with me raiſe you to the higheſt eſtimation.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O Clorinda! that word pronounc'd,
Think what you do enjoin me.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I fear'd before you knew me,
But thought it fitter to practiſe the maſculine part
I am to play, with you, then with another:
Perhaps with ſome I have to do, where my
Diſcovery is my ruine. Thus much, confident
Of your eſteem, I dare diſcover.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: What muſick's in theſe words!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Truſt me, Prince Clarimant, I am much pleas'd
To ſee you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Madam, aſſure me that I do not dream.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Believe me every ſenſe is free,
Only your joy is too much rais'd.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Too much! when you ſpeak to me, and not in anger.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Contain your ſelf; for know 'tis in your Power
To make me happy.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: In mine! witneſs you God •
There is no bar betwixt you and your wiſh.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: None but your will.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: My will! That, and my other faculties
Were ever yours.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Swear it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: By all that's ſacred, it is and ever ſhall be ſo;
For you can will nothing but what is juſt
And noble.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: My will then is, to which yours muſt aſſent,
That you do kill me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: A miſerable life conſider'd, death is the happineſs
Oppoſed: That you muſt give me, or be perjur'd.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: That Clarimant ſhould kill Clorinda!
Self-murder is eſteem'd the higheſt guilt,
And yet this doubles it: I am deluded
By ſome ſpirit; for what proportion
Bears this impoſition to your excellent ſweetneſs?

sp.speaker: Clo:
sp.l: It bears proportion to my ſorrows.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Could death be granted as your only remedy,
Yet that my hand ſhould give it!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Thoſe ſervants are eſteem'd the trueſt,
That do the laſt and greateſt offices of duty.
Having no love to pay your vows of ſervice,
My gratitude propoſed this as your recompence.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O heavens! was ever gratitude ſo cruel!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Will you not then obey me, nor your oath?
Is this the fruit of all your proteſtations?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Is not my will the ſame with yours?
You would not live, nor I then.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Kill me, and then do what you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The ſame ſay I; kill me, and then do what you pleaſe:

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Your vow was not to eccho my deſire,
But to obey what I enjoind.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: It is true, in what was juſt and noble.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Is it not ſo to relieve a friend diſtreſt?
Your oath paſt too?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: No friend will ask, for ſhame,
The help does refuſe to give.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: The guilt remains with the firſt breach, and that was yours.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Alas, you preſs what no example yet came near,
To kill that perſon that I value more
Then all the world.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: No doubt brave Brutus ſervant lov'd his Maſter;
Yet kill'd him, being commanded.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Perhaps he was his ſlave, and gain'd his
Freedom by it.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: And ſhall not you do ſo? A freedom from the bonds
Of Love, the Tyrant-maſter that I flie. But did not
Herod
Doom to death in one his Wife and Miſtreſs,
Leſt any other ſhould enjoy her?
And this cauſed from exceſs of Love.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Unto himſelf, as I dare never hope
To be ſo happy to have his intereſt,
So I ſhall never fear his puniſhment. [Kneels]
This is that poſture which my former vows
Beſt ſuit withall: Nor am I humbled thus,
To beg for pitty to my ſelf but you,
Divine Clorinda! who ought to be
As far from thought of puniſhment,
As you are free from guilt.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Falſe perjur'd man! I can be free from neither,
Whilſt I ſtay here.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O miſery! was ever man ſo wretched!
In the performing what ſhe ſhould command,
I ſtill have plac'd my only hopes of merit.
Sure fate did never yet to any Lover
Put ſo hard a part,
To diſobey, or pierce his Miſtreſs heart.

div.head: Act. 2. Scaen. 1.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: COme ſir, you muſt not be ſo ſad:
Sure there is ſome ſtrange ſympathie betwixt
Prince Clarimant and you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: No ſympathie at all, if he have any cauſe
Of grief; mine's meerly natural.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I find you diſſemble with me:
Your griefs have ſuch reſemblance, that knowing his
Is Love, I am aſſured yours is the ſame.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Love! I honour all the ſex, yet never knew
That paſſion for a woman.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs that you have in your ſelf
So much of beauty, that looking in your glaſs,
It is not like you ſhould be taken with anothers form:
But yet take heed, the Gods may puniſh pride.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: To be ſuch, is a puniſhment ſo great,
The Gods can add no more.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: The intereſt you have in the King, hath made me
Study your content: I find my ſister loves you;
And what her bluſhes will not let her ſpeak,
I muſt.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: If ſhe herſelf ſhould tell me ſo, it were fit for me
To think ſhe ſaid it to make ſport, knowing
My own unworthineſs.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: How ſlow ſoever you are of belief,
muſt make known a Ladies paſſion to you
Every way your equal.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I have not ſeen that perſon, ſure.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: What do you think of me?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: You! as of the ſoul of all perfection,
And only worthy him you do enjoy.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I muſt not think my beauty worth eſteem:
For, gaining him, there is a conqueſt, which obtain'd,
Deſerves a triumph. That bluſh ſhews you conceive me.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Madam, it is impoſſible I ſhould underſtand
A ſpeech ſo diſagreeing to that character
I had received.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: It will be unjuſt to value me the leſs
For my eſteem of you.

sp.speaker: Clo:
sp.l: Of me!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Know, gentle Youth, not all the tyes of duty
Have power to bar me the expreſſions of love,
That grows from ſuch perfections as the world
Never knew: Hide not that lovely face,
Which even the King beholding, muſt excuſe me.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Thou lyeſt, falſe woman.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: O Agenor! I never wiſht thee half ſo miſerable.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Why do you turn away? What, weep! Is my love
Such an injury? Or if ſome word have paſt my lips,
That mov'd this paſſion, my lips ſhall ſatisfie
By taking off theſe tears.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I can endure no more:
Juſt heavens, how my inconſtancie is puniſht!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Clear up thoſe Suns, and let them gently ſhine upon me,
Or I am loſt for ever! Not moved with all my
Courtſhip,
Continue thus unkind, inſenſible of a Queens love,
And I ſhall think you are no man.

sp.speaker: Clor.
sp.l: The weakneſs of my paſſion hath diſcover'd me:
Madam, ſuch an exceſs of happineſs
To be thus favour'd by you, produc'd this paſſion;
Tears are as well the effect of joy as ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: A woman, I am confident! Now I can read it
In her face, ſir. I accept of your excuſe,
But then you muſt forgo this ſadneſs.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Madam, all other thoughts but the conſideration
Of your favour, are henceforth baniſht.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I yet am ſomething doubtful of your profeſſions,
You may confirm me.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Sure you have a Miſtreſs, ſome in the Court
That you do love.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: None, truſt me.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Then you do love the King ſo much, that you hate me
For my inconſtancie, you may forgive it, I know he will;
He thinks it is no vice, rather a vertue,
To have choice of Miſtreſſes.—Why do you ſigh?
This touches; nay, now you break your promiſe.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Madam, I am not well.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Will you reſt your ſelf upon my bed?
I'll call the King, then you will be well,
It is he muſt cure you, Lady.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Lady! O my heart— [Swoons]

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: What have I done? ho, ſome Cordial quickly!
Help—

div.l: Madam, he recovers.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Lay him upon my bed, gently for heavens ſake!
In this diſcovery I my end obtain,
But make proviſion for my future pain.
Such fruit our jealouſie produces ſtill:
Better not know, then know the worſt of ill.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Pray you ſir, ſhall I make bold to ask a queſtion?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: A dozen, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: You are courteous. Why was the King ſent for by the
Queen in ſuch haſte?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I muſt not tell you that.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Perhaps you cannot.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I cannot, ſir, be ignorant.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: O, wondrous eaſie; perhaps the King knew not
The cauſe himſelf.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: It may be ſo; Kings know not all things.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: You do, it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Seem, ſir!

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Nay, be not angry; you promis'd largely.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I promis'd nothing.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: 'Tis true; and nothing I expect. So fare you well.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Remember, ſir, I only gave you leave to ask.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: 'Tis true, I cry you mercy:
Then I May ask one queſtion more.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You may ask any thing.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Do you not think I had ill luck
To find a man ſo overwiſe for my Informer.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Troth ſir—

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: You need not anſwer, I am already
Satisfied.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I ſee you know not me,
You are a ſhallow fellow.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: And you ſo deep a puddle,
No plummet can find the bottom;
You have no ground, ſir: So fare you well,
My cautious Monſieur.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: O dear Clorinda! how powerfully thy beauties
Now preſent themſelves, and minute gather ſtrength
By theſe thy ſufferings! What cauſe haſt thou and I
To curſe my baſe inconſtancie?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: How ſir! are you ſo ingrate to heaven,
That for your ſake favour'd that vice ſo far,
To give it the reward of vertue, happineſs?
And that ſo great in your Auſtela,
That all men elſe are poor compared.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: My Auſtela!

sp.speaker: Au:
sp.l: It is well I am denied then▪

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Did ſhe not court you as a man?
The heart ſhe took from me, through you could not
Receive, your ſex denying Entertain,
Is yet ſo tainted in the tender of it,
That I for ever muſt repent the change
I made: O Clorinda! would this hand
