When it was join'd in hers, had rotted off.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Do you believe to cure inconſtancie
And breach of faith, by new inconſtancie?
I ſee it was a vice dwelt in your blood.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: It is no inconſtancie, to caſt an eye back
On your vertue, too late inſtructed
By preſent miſery.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: It is enough; this does expreſs how miſerable
You might have been: But know your happineſs is perfect.
The Queen prompted by jealouſie, the fruit of
Ardent love, ſuſpected me a woman,
And your former Miſtreſs, and took this way of courting me
To be aſſured.

sp.speaker: Age▪
sp.l: Your vertue bids you make this fair conſtruction.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: She comes! her ſight begets new trouble;
Would I had chang'd this habit for my winding-ſheet.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Sir, I am glad to find my chamber can afford you
So good company.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Abſence at any rate! I muſt be gone:
Your Majeſties pardon.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: It ſeems you have cured him.

sp.speaker: Age▪
sp.l: You made him ſick; had I not reaſon?
It is fit I remedy your errors.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: You have ſo many of your own,
It will take your time up.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: But there's one eſpecially that troubles me.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: You would change a wife, would you not?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Do your thoughts prompt you to that queſtion?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: It is time when you deny me.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: There was a time I might.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Had your hand rotted off, the preſent trouble
Had been ſaved: You are an unconſtant man;
Which granted, both are miſerable.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Both are no leſs in being jealous,
Which you muſt grant you are.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Having ſuch cauſe, love could not be without it.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: But having certainty that vertue is gone,
Love ceaſing▪ ends that trouble.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: The object of our guilt, ſhall be our Judge.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I doe not underſtand your riddle: who do you mean?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: One, that to me cannot be partiall▪ your Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Yes, Clorinda.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: But doe you think that you ſtand clear in honor.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: You cannot hope it ſure; but there's the more
For me to pardon: Come, all your paſſages of love
Are plain; yours, and your brother Clarimants.
Perſwade Clorinda that I think her ſtill a man,
Leſt modeſty make her forſake the Court,
And both uſe means to make her love your brother.
Theſe little quarrels, where the hearts are good,
The body of our Love keeps firm, like letting blood.
Come. thou ſhalt lend me ten Crowns;
As I am an honeſt man, Ile pay thee.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Gain that opinion with me firſt:
You ſee the Money's ready.
Why, thou haſt known me long,
Did I ever deceive thee.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: No, for I ever took thee for a Shark:
A Fellow too, that would abuſe me
In my poverty, in words.
It was but in Merriment; I ſwear I ever
Loved thee truly.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Yes, and I wil requite it; I know that mony
Would but dull your Wit, ſpoil Induſtry:
I finde it by my ſelf, that care keeps cloſe
My Purſe.
Refuſe a Comrade little Coyn:
• Iis poor.

sp.speaker: Clind
sp.l: But yet the cuſtome of the Rich, and things
Muſt be proportion'd to our Fortune.
'Tis well Fortune and you are friends;
That makes you proud.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: I have a ſenſe of her great benefits, I were a Fool elſe.
Well! I may live to repay this ſcorn.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Yes, ſooner then the Money you would borrow;
Which makes me ask no Bond.
Come, prethee ſupply me, and leave fooling.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Spare your own pains, Sir, you have done enough.
As I am clad, I am not fit for any honeſt company.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Nor cloath'd in Scarlet truſt me.
You are a baſe Fellow: the Tide may turn.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: O admirable fruit of poverty! Valour infus'd I vow:
Yet remember, Friend, quarrels are dangerous.
Tell me of danger—

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: I cry you mercy, Sir; I had forgot you were poor.
Nay, if you be outragious, I muſt leave you.
We ſhall meet agen.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Yes, no doubt on't; how calm and temperate
Will Money make one: a man might almoſt pull me
By the Noſe, yet I not angry; ſuch admirable ſatisfactions
Here.—
This Youth I have ſeen oft, had a ſtrange
Mind to talk to him; yet ſtill the brat avoids me.
Stay my pretty knave, ſhall I borrow a word or two

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: On good ſecurity you will ask no more.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l:
Why is your Miſtreſs ſtaying for you i •
the Lobby?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l:
If ſhe were, what would you give to ſuppl •
my room?

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: I do believe what ever it were, ſhe would repay the ſum.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l:
O fie! you look not like an Amoriſt; tha •
face would fright her.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l:
A martial one: Adonis was not alwaye •
favourite,
Mars had his turn.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Were you that Deity? your reign is out.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: But I can prove a Jupiter, and court your
Miſtreſs in a ſhower
Of gold; and that, I take it, in all times is powerful
More then your face.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Deſcend, deſcend, and ſhew yourſelf a ſimple Mortal▪
Elſe I ſhall leave you.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Tell me firſt what Country you are of;
My mind gives me I have ſeen that face.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: You have a fooliſh mind that does abuſe you,
So fare you well.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: And ſo have you a fooliſh tongue that does betray you;

A certain coy diſdainful look too, that ſtiles you •
woman.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: How ſir! you ſhall find me maſculine; take that.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: This cannot hide you; confeſs your ſex and name,
Or by this light I will untruſs your points,
And then you know what follows.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Sir, you in this reſtraint preſerve my modeſty,
It was my deſire that you ſhould know me:
I dare not ſay you are the cauſe of this diſguiſe,
Yet you may think your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Now by this light have I mind to beat thee
As a man, for all the ſcorns thou haſt put upon me:
For as a woman I am ſure thou wilt abuſe me,
Eſpecially if thou pretend'ſt to love me.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Your ſcorn's ſo juſt, that I muſt ſuffer it:

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: How! let's ſee; no moiſture! ſpare, ſpare your
Linen, good Selina.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Oh whither ſhall I flie to hide my ſhame!

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Ev'n to your mask and petticoat: Carry your bum
A little out, you will need no Fardingale a while.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Alas ſir you miſtake, I have no other burden
But my ſorrows; from thoſe you only can deliver me.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Bar marriage, and I will be your midwife:
Where lie you?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: As you have honour in you, do not diſcover me,
Hereafter you ſhall know.

div.stage: Enter Clorinda (with a paper) and Olinda.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Madam, having received ſuch teſtimonies
Of your favor, I could not leave the Court
Even in civility, till I had kiſt your fair hand.

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: What ſad things do you utter! It is not poſſible,
You do but fright me ſure.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Neceſſity enforces; for I ſhall leave behind
That which I value far above my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: Does the King and Queen know what you do intend?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: They muſt not.

sp.speaker: Olin
sp.l: Your reſolution is full of cruelty;
That though you do oblige me by imparting it,
Yet I muſt fail your truſt, and give them notice.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: For your own ſake you muſt not: this paper,
I being gone, will let you know a ſecret
That concerns your happineſs, and by my ſtay
You will be miſerable.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: Alas, that is impoſſible:
To have your company, includes all joys.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Since you eſteem it ſo, if I live I will return.

sp.speaker: Olin.
sp.l: How ſoon?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: In a ſhort time; but if you read this paper
Yet this two days, when I come back you have my curſe.
Weep not dear Lady, yield me the honor
Of your hand.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: O me moſt wretched! you ſhall not go,
I die if you thus leave me.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Alas I muſt.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Madam, I cannot chuſe but wonder
To ſee you court a Boy thus.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: My wonder is greater at your arrogance
And ignorance, to tutor me, and ſlight a perſon
Then your ſelf more worthy.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: What's this?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: From him I may receive that death I ſeek:
Defend your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Ah me! help, help! oh help Prince Clarimant,
The gentle Youth is hurt.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Hurt!
O heavens, grant me a little ſpace.

div.stage: Clar. fights with the Prince, beats him off, returns wounded, and kneels to Clorinda.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Why this to me?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: To ask your pardon, that he lives
That drew that precious blood.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I grieve your hurt, yet thank you not for interpoſing.

div.l: My Brother wounded! ſpeak, by whom? A surgeon, quick.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: The Prince of Aquitain.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Make after, ſeiſe him:
Dear Clarimant, how is it with you?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Well; happy to die for ſuch a cauſe.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: You Gods extend your pitty: O dear Clorinda!
• our ſome balm into his wounds.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: One word from you may clear his fainting ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Clo
sp.l: Heaven knows I wiſh his life more then mine own.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: We muſt do more then wiſh.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Although my reaſon tels me that I owe my thanks
To your deſpair, yet the ſound comforts me:
O there beſtow your cure! my cure lies there.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Thou ſoul of Lovers, in thee dwels ſuch truth,
Well may thy merit ſave our faithleſs Youth.

div.head: Act. 3. Scaen. I.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: IS there no news? what is become of this rude Prince?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: You need not ſeek for him; his wounds and his diſgrace
Are puniſhment enough.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: My reaſon now does tell me ſo; but had my brothers
Wounds prov'd mortal, no corner of the earth
Should hide him from my revenge.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I cannot chuſe but grieve the ſad accident;
Yet know I am oblig'd in honor, he coming
To my reſcue with ſuch a powerful Fleet,
To look with leſs ſeverity upon his fault:
Beſides, which happily you know not,
I gave him leave to be a ſuiter to my daughter.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: His puniſhment would be ſo great to ſee Clorinda,
As herſelf whom he would then have wounded
As his rival, that I confeſs I wiſh him here.
Beſides, thoſe of his Fleet, or he ſcaping to
That, may do ſome ſudden miſchief.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: He cannot be ſo baſe, your fears are needleſs.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Madam, in modeſty I could no longer
Wear the habit of a man, once known a woman:
But humbly I beſeech you on my knees,
〈◊〉 you reſpect the honor of our ſex,
When you return, to licence my departure
From the Court; ſince miſery and diſcontent
• wels here, though I were circled in
With all thoſe honors you or the King can grant.

sp.speaker: Auſt.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs I am made happy by your miſery,
And therefore hold my ſelf oblig'd to ſtudy always
For your ſatisfaction. But know, beſides this tye,
• have ſo great opinion of your merit,
Hold it ſo far to exceed mine, that I am confident
The Gods reſerve for you a greater bleſſing then Agenor,
A perſon tainted in his faith.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Although your own, I muſt not ſuffer
Such an undervalue of the King, whoſe worth is ſuch,
So far exceeding all, that it admits of an allay.
Here it was not ſo, rather addition;
A change produc'd by ſuch perfection,
Is not to be eſteem'd inconſtancie, but wiſdom:

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: It is not now, rather hereafter that I ſhall return
This argument upon your ſelf: Now let us go do
What charity enjoins.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: That and my duty forces me to attend you.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: How is it with your Highneſs?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O too well, Clindor: my outward wounds
Heal much too faſt, ſince theſe within do feſter.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Well ſir, you little know what ſervice I may do you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I know thou haſt and wilt be careful of my health.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: But ſir, I mean that I can ſerve you in your love.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O Clindor; ſpeak no more; thou troubleſt me.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Will it trouble you to let you know Clorinda's here?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Here! where?

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Not in this room, but in this Country, nay in this Court.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Alas I know it, and ſo by this does all men.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: But do they know Selina's here in habit of a man?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: But yet they do not know ſhe is in love with me,
Moſt deſperately too.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Nor doſt thou know it, fool,
ſhe does abuſe thee.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: She dares not; by this light I will beat her.—
The Surgeons, ſir, are come to dreſs you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Muſt I be dreſt?

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: The Queen your ſiſter! Clorinda, as I live, ſir.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O fool, thou lyeſt; it is impoſſible— Can it be ſhe?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Brother, how is with you now?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: So well, that I could kiſs that ſword that made theſe
Wounds; for I by them receive a benefit
Which I durſt never hope.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Come, I muſt dreſs your wounds; no common hand
Is fit to touch you. I know this Lady will apply
One plaiſter, ſince for her ſake you did receive
Theſe wounds.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Led by your example, I am compell'd to follow.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You Gods, what happineſs is this! may they be long
A healing, if ſtill this application will continue.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Pray not againſt your ſelf, heaven is offended,
Granting your requeſt, I fear; for if I not miſtake,
They bleed afreſh. Fair Clorinda,
Theſe drops expreſs his paſſion, and your power.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I grieve for both, and know no remedy ſo good
As a perpetual abſence.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Know dear Clorinda, it was a thankful heart
That ſent thoſe few drops forth to kiſs your hand
For ſo great favours: your cruel reſolution
Sends them back, their errand ſcarce perform'd:
For ſee, I bleed no more; but know withall
'Tis the deſtruction of the fountain; the coldneſs
Of deſpair muſt quickly freeze all motion:

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I owe a reverence to that blood upon this hand;
O let me kiſs it as a moſt ſacred relique
Of the trueſt Lover the ſex did ever boaſt.
That ſpot, Clorinda, you may wipe away,
But never ſhall the memory of him
Whom you thus cruelly do murder
By diſdain.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Madam, free from that guilt, I cannot apprehend
A puniſhment. The Gods are juſt; they be my witneſs
If I had happineſs to give, I ſhould prefer
This Prince before my ſelf; But I am ſuch a peece
Of earth, ſo ſunk beneath all joys,
That ſhould I yield what he can ask,
Yet I muſt lie like lead upon his heart.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Yet for the preſent, ſure,
It is fit you ſpeak comfort to him.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Comfort from me! 'tis contradiction
To my being, who am made up of miſery.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Pray come near, and ſpeak to him.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I am ſo careful, that I would not hurt him.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Brother, be confident her rigor cannot laſt,
I ſhall perſwade her to relent.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O Madam, you miſtake; ſhe only hath the beauties,
And not the weakneſſes uſually depending on her ſex:
Her reſolutions have their ground from reaſon ever,
And know no change till it command.
How can ſhe then eſteem the leſs deſerving brother
Worthy her love, when he that moſt deſerved
Foully betraid her? Life could only prove
No curſe, if I might be aſſur'd ſhe would
Forgive the injury ſhe ſuffers by the trouble
Of my love; to hope her pitty of my torments,
Is much above my faith.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Madam, too long we have diſturb'd the Prince;
Our abſence would be more conducing to his health.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: There is a care his merits methinks ſhould command
Over your gratitude: which that you not apply,
Too late you may repent.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I ſo much wiſh his health and happineſs,
That I will ever pray that he may never find
Diſquiet thought, and to my prayers likewiſe add
My lateſt counſel: Forget Clorinda, and make her happy.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Forget Clorinda, and make her happy!
How can I underſtand this cruel ſentence?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Waſte not your ſpirits, ſir; I think I underſtand her,
And it ſhall not be long ere I procure her
To explain herſelf.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You are the comfort of my love, and life.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: What do I owe my ſtars that did direct me
To this place, where I find ſafety for my perſon,
Cure for my wounds, and ſuch a friend who chalks me
Out a way to all I can deſire on earth!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Follow my counſel, and be conſtant in it,
You are the maſter of your wiſh▪

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Conſtant! can there be other ends propos'd
Powerful to change me? Revenge for my diſgrace;
And the poſſeſſion of that Kingdom I aim'd at
In Auſtela, now to prove mine with one I more eſteem,
The fair Olinda. But how when this is done,
I ever can requite your pains?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: It pays it ſelf; and to ſecure you more
Of my intention and performance,
Know I am not the man I have appeared,
But one whom both revenge and love does likewiſe
Animate.—
My Inſtrument returns:
When we have heard what's his intelligence,
I will lay my ſelf more fully open,
And we'll conclude how to purſue what we deſign.
What is thy news, good?

sp.speaker: Druid.
sp.l: As you could wiſh.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: We'll hear't within.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: A man ſo holy and ſo knowing, ſayſt thou,
That can give com • orts to all griefs,
Call back the peace that is fled from any mind?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Certainly, Madam, the ſpirit of the Gods
Dwels in him, or rather he is a God deſcended
To the earth to comfort the diſtreſſed world:
I am confident, had you but once diſcours'd with him,
You would not be thus ſad.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: O fool! the Gods themſelves have not a cure for me
But death: If he their ſubſtitute would give me that,
Then I would viſit him moſt gladly. Prethee leave me.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Well Madam, I grieve you have not faith
To truſt my words. My words! nay, all the City
Speaks him Wonderful for ſanctity and knowledg.

sp.speaker: Clo▪
sp.l: Well, perhaps I will ſee him: Prethee now leave me.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Alas Madam, I cannot, whilſt you are thus ſad.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I am not ſo, thou but deceiveſt thy ſelf;
Or if I be, company makes me worſe.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Madam, ſince I muſt, yet ſtill my duty
Preſſes you to receive this comfort.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Well, be gone, I will think on it.
Why do I trifle time out thus, when every hour
I feel a torment more then death can be?
Beſides, if I were gone; from the impoſſibility
To enjoy me, Prince Clarimants affection
Might abate; and yet when I conſider,
His love appears none of thoſe ſickly paſsions
Which time can triumph over, ſince I believe it ſuch,
Where is my gratitude to ſee him languiſh?
Nay, to ſee him die? die of thoſe wounds
That he for me received? I never can forget
His blood freſh ſtreaming from his wounds
At my approach; that faithful witneſs of his joy,
More worthy of belief, then if a thouſand tongues
Or pens ſhould be imployed: I find my ſelf
More wretched now then ever, fitter to die;
For if I live, I to my own ſhall add
His ſufferings too: And yet methinks that ſhould be
Pleaſing: To grieve for him, is to diſcharge
Part of that debt I owe; I would not be ungrateful:
Live then Clorinda, till thou find'ſt ſome way
To make him happy. No, it is impoſſible,
Since I cannot • e ſo; yet I may ſeem content,
And by that ſeeming give him real bleſſing:
And ſee, fortune preſents an object that confirms my hopes
It may be done, at leaſt I will endeavour.

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: Deareſt Clorinda! not leſs dear, becauſe a woman;
For ſuch perfections in a man I ſolely could not
Have poſſeſt, my own defects barring that happineſs:
But as a woman ſure, none can pretend
With greater merit to your favour;
All my wants ſupplied by my firm love,
Which cannot know another object then your fair ſelf.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I muſt eſteem my ſelf moſt happy
In the continuance of your love,
Rather your friendſhip; for all affection
Is from us proper to the better ſex.

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: Which ſure is ours, you being a woman.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Your ſiſter will not grant you that,
Whoſe example you ought to follow, in acknowledging
Love and ſuperiority due to the men,
Eſpecially ſuch men as the King Agenor
And his more worthy brother Clarimant.

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: Theſe words of Clarimant, if heard,
Would cauſe a general joy through all the Court:
But he himſelf muſt know his happineſs by degrees,
Leſt the exceſs again diſturb his health;
Since your laſt viſit he is miraculouſly recover'd.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: You attribute to me what is more juſtly due
Unto the King and Queen's, nay your ſweet converſation.
Methinks you four would be moſt aptly join'd;
Two brothers and two ſiſters, whoſe perfections
All the world cannot equal.

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: Dear Clorinda, I muſt not underſtand you;
Or if I do, you have a mean opinion
Of my Judgment, leſs of my Conſtancie,
Which did but now profeſs my heart for ever only yours:

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I take for granted that your heart is mine,
Which I expreſs in that I would diſpoſe it,
And ſo I would do my own, if I had any:
But know that what I once do give I never reaſſume;
Or if I had a heart, could that be worthy Clarimant
Another had deſpiſed?

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: What now you ſpeak to me, expreſſes your reſpect to him,
And ſo muſt not diſpleaſe; for I confeſs
His merits are ſo great, that in his happineſs
All that love vertue muſt be ſharers:
But I beſeech you do not entertain a thought
That you can breed a change in him or me.
Dear Clorinda, your vertue and your beauty
Is the object of our Loves; ſuch a conformity
As may ariſe from that, betwixt Prince Clarimant
And me, is only fit.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I for my part do ask no more, but that your lines
Of love do meet in me: But reaſon in him,
Friendſhip in you may give me power in time
To tie a happy knot; this hope the Gods inſpire me with.

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: Take heed, they needs muſt be offended with you
For a hope that is ſo unjuſt.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Dare you refer your ſelf unto their ſentence?

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: I dare do any thing that you think fit;
But this I know you cannot.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Heaven knows that I deſire it.

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: But do not hope it, when two wills oppoſe you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Yet when the Gods ſhall give their ſentence,
Your will and Clarimant's, it all your vows be true,
Muſt then ſubmit to mine.

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: Should we grant our obedience, how have the Gods,
Or can they unto us declare their will?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: That great Deity that did infuſe
A reaſonable ſoul into us mortals,
Inthron'd that Reaſon as a King to govern
All our actions. But beyond this I am inform'd,
Nor is it poſſible but you muſt know it,
That here without the City in a ſacred Grove,
There lives a man ſo pious, and ſo knowing
The will of heaven, that all men in diſtreſs
Or doubt repair to him, and find a happy iſſue
Of their troubles.

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: It is moſt true, his fame is great:
If curioſity do move you to go viſit him,
I gladly will attend you; but ſince I have reſiſted
What you commanded, dear Clorinda,
No mortal man muſt change me.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I love this firmneſs in you; the fitter you
Will prove hereafter for Clarimants affection.
In hearts of wax, Love eaſily impreſſions make,
But thoſe of diamonds hardly new forms take.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Clindor, I make no doubt your joy is not the leaſt
To ſee your Maſter thus recover'd of his wounds.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Faith ſir, his outward wounds are pretty well;
But there's a fooliſh ſhaft ſticks in his heart.
The little Archer ſhould be whipt for ſhooting Soldiers,
What has he to do with us?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: He aims ſtill at the nobleſt marks.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: But thoſe, ſir, that are wiſe, wear privy coats,
And then his darts prove but burbolts, and drop down
At our feet: And is not that, ſir, better then by our whining
Or in verſe or proſe, make theſe ſhe-goſſips think themſelves
Our Deities, who by creation rather are our ſlaves.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I ſee thou art an enemy to Love.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Juſt as to Idleneſs: why are we not in arms?
Methinks there is now a brave occaſion.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: How? we have no enemies▪

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Let's make ſome then: But ſir, you have a cauſe
Of juſt revenge againſt that baſe Prince which hurt your Brother:
Let's fall upon his Country, they ſay a rich one,
And he no doubt lies here obſcured to do ſome miſchief:
At leaſt let us ſeiſe upon his ſhips here in the road.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: It were diſhonorable:
He came to the aſſiſtance of the King my father,
And for his ſake I rather do deſire his friendſhip,
However he appears not to receive it.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: That ſhews his hatred; he may be in his Country
Raiſing forces to invade your Kingdom in your abſence:
Prevent him ſir, and ſeiſe on his; it is a ſhame, ſir,
To lie here hugging a wife, waſting your beſt of youth
On poor delights.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Thou knowſt not what it is to be rich in pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Yes▪ to have mony purchas'd by my ſword.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Is it not as well to have it without blows?

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Not by the half: If your Majeſty ſhould give me now
A thouſand crowns, in the mind I am in,
I ſwear I ſcarce would give you thanks for it.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Well Clindor, I had ſuch an intention; but ſince I ſee
It will be no more acceptable, it ſhall be reſerv'd for ſome other.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Your Majeſty, if you pleaſe, may lend me ſuch a ſum:
At the firſt City taken by aſſault, I ſhall pay it.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: The war is ſo diſtant from my thoughts,
So long I cannot ſpare it.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Nay, as you pleaſe ſir, I am full.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Able to lend me, are you not? I am a ſtranger here,
And may need gold.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Make haſte, ſir, back to Burgonia, your credit's good there:
And to ſay truth, I wonder why you ſtay ſo long;
Your ſubjects will believe you have forgot them,
Your fathers death, ſir, left things much unſetled.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Clindor, I thank you for your care; 'tis worth my thought,
And ſhall be worth to you the thouſand crowns we ſpake of,
Nor ſhall you pay ſo much as thanks to me:
Only be careful of my brother; he is full of melancholy,
For which I know no better cure then your company.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: He ſhall not ſtir a foot without me:
But this ſame fooliſh Love does trouble us; A little
Bout, ſir,
In the field, War, war would cure us all.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Divine Clorinda! how quickly is my joy
To ſee you here, loſt by the cruelty of your commands!
All your neglect was juſt; but now to bid me
Ceaſe to love you, nay to impoſe a new affection,
It is ſuch a ſtudied tyrannie, that I in this particular
To Gods and men may juſtifie my diſobedience
To Clorinda.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I muſt not hope that any argument
That I have uſed can be of equal force
With her perfections; if they want power,
'Tis vain to plead it further: but henceforth
Be aſſured I never ſhall impoſe any command
Upon you, nor will I ever ſee you more,
If with convenience I may avoid you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Stay, you cannot think it is poſſible
I ſhould obey you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I think you will not rather; ſo fare you well.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O ſtay! was ever man ſo wretched?
May I not be allowed ſome time to try
If I can be unconſtant?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: How long?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Two or three days.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Oh! years, years will not do it, ſure not an age,
I cannot ſuffer ſuch a thought: To pierce my heart
Is much more eaſie; O give me leave to do that
Rather; then you ſhall ſee your character
So deeply printed there, that not Clorinda's ſelf
Can ere deface it, not by this injury,
Although the greateſt that ever yet was offer'd
To a faithful love.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Tears from thoſe manly eyes! it is not fit I urge it more:
But know withall it is impiety in you
To hope I ever can be yours:
For though no contract paſt betwixt me
And the King your brother, I hold my ſelf
Unfit to be anothers wife; my vows of being
Ever his, are ſure in heaven recorded.
Think ſeriouſly of this; but withall be aſſured
That perſon does not live to whom I hold
My ſelf ſo much obliged as to Prince Clarimant:
The Gods grant you much peace,
Nay greater happineſs then they permit me to beſtow.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Thunder and muſick in one voice; deſpair and joy!
• et reaſon bids me hope from her laſt word:
The heart that pitties once, may love afford.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Selina, I am now reſolved to ſee this
Holy man; and if he be what you relate,
Hereafter I ſhall credit you. Prince Clarimant
And fair Olinda too will go along:
Let it be order'd ſo, if poſſible,
That none take notice of our going.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: That may with much eaſe be effected: Some houres
As in the morning he wholly dedicates
To his devotions, and does admit of none to viſit him:
But perſons of your quality are not obliged to any rule.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: It fals out happily; be ready then to guide us.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Madam, I ſhall not fail; and if you find him not above
What you expect, for ever baniſh me your favor.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Auſtela, I much wonder why this
Unhappy Prince appears not.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Doubtleſs, ſir, he is ſhipt; the ſenſe of his diſgrace
Will hinder him for ever appearing in this Court.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Why ſho • ld you think ſo? his action was not ſuch
As you would make it; although Clorinda
Were a woman, he knew it not, but as a rival
In your ſiſters love did wound her.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: That is true, ſir; it is not that which I alleadg •
In his diſgrace, but that he with ſuch odds
Could not defend himſelf from Clarimant.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: It was his misfortune, and not want of courage,
Nor can I think that he conſented
To that aſſiſtance which his ſervants gave:
However I muſt value him a friend,
For ſuch he ſhewed himſelf in my diſtreſs;
Nor ſhall he ſuffer in my Kingdom, if it lie
In my power to ſerve him.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I am not, ſir, to counſel you: but for my part
The little knowledg I had of him, does make me wiſh
Never to ſee my ſiſter married to him;
And I am confident, if not inforc'd,
She never will receive him for a husband.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: It is not come to that: I rather fear
His wounds were mortal; and ſhould he thus be loſt
And no accompt given of his life or death,
It might be prejudicial to my honor,
All neighbour Princes would avoid my Court for ever.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: It were no loſs, if they were all like him.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Daughter, I find you are ſo partial for your
Husbands brother, that you forget my intereſt quite:

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I cannot be ſo ſevered by a husband,
As to forget a loving father: My ſiſters good
Obliges to ſpeak thus much, for whom
I muſt believe Prince Clarimant would prove
A nobler husband then this Prince
You ſo much ſeem to favour.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: It is true; but his affection's ſetled on Clorinda ſure,
Never to be altered.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: You know not, ſir, what time may do;
Clorinda's ſelf labours to make Prince Clarimant
Change his affection to my ſiſter: For her,
She vows never to marry, as having loſt Agenor
Whom ſhe loved. This I both gather by mine
Own obſervance, and likewiſe know it from my ſiſter,
To whom Clorinda hath in part expreſt as much.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Things ſtanding ſo, I muſt confeſs, if honor
And my word engag'd permit, I quickly ſhould conſent.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: You would have reaſon. I know Agenor
So much loves his brother, that he might be perſwaded
After your death to live here, and leave the government
Of Burgonia to Clarimant.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: It were a high point of ſtate, could it be ſo,
And we ſhould aptly pay the care we owe
Unto this Kingdom. That State is much more happy
Where the Prince himſelf remains,
Then howſoever govern'd by a Subſtitute.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Add to this, what happineſs it were for me
To live here in that Kingdom, which I
By your favour brought my husband.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: My dear Auſtela, I rejoice in thy inſtruction:
My daughter and my Tutor, to thy cleer
Judgment I leave the managing of this affair.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Will you not let them ſee my art?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: No, no, it were loſs of time.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: On peril of your lives keep cloſe, till you be call'd.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Speak not of calling;
As ſoon as you perceive them once entred
This thicket, break forth and ſeiſe them:
If any men come in their company,
Unleſs they yield, kill them; whilſt we convey
Away the Ladies to the ſhip. Where lies the Boat?
Who guides to that?

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: Faſt by here in a Creek.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: But why ſhould not we rather let them come
Unto his Cell? then we might better ſeiſe them.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Oh by no means! he muſt remain here ſtill
In the ſame reputation, untill by poiſon
Or ſome other way the King Agenor be diſpatcht;
And then come to receive a D • kedom
For thy recompence,—or elſe a halter.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Doubt not, I will deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: My mind miſgives me that they will not come.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Oh fear it not; both love and curioſity
Advance their ſteps, either of which
Hath power to make young people run:
The boy that brings them, hath his intereſt too:
I judge it near the time.
I ſee them coming.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Stand cloſe.

div.stage: Enter Selina, Clorinda, Clarimant, Olinda, Clindor.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Madam, it is but a little farther
Within the Wood.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Whilſt they enquire for Oracles,
I'll talk with you: It is a notable witty rogue—
The place methinks invites:

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Traitors!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Help, help, you Gods!

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Make good 'gainſt them.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Loſe no time.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O Clindor, that we had wings!

div.stage: In the fight Sailors are kill'd.

div.head: Act. 4. Scaen. 1.
div.stage: Enter King, Agenor, Auſtela, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: 'TIs ſtrange that they ſhould be ſo long returning,
It is not a mile without the City.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: It ſeems they find a pleaſing entertainment.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: O my heart! what object's this!

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Clindor, what mean theſe wounds?

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: To kill me, ſir, I think; and if they do,
It matters not, life hath with me no value:
Your Brother's loſt.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: How loſt?

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Surpris'd by the baſe Prince of Aquitain,
As they were going to ſee the holy Druid.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: O heavens! and whither carried?

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: To his Fleet that lies here in the Road.
Prince Clarimant and I, when we had kill'd
Thoſe that oppoſed us, purſued to overtake them,
But came juſt as they put their Barge from ſhore:
The Prince not conſidering his wounds,
Tranſported by his paſſion, leaps into the ſea,
And ſwam after the Boat; but you may think
In vain, although he could have reacht it.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: And ſo was drown'd!

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: Not drown'd, but perhaps worſe:

Whether moved by the Ladies prayers, or that they
〈◊〉 might not
Loſe the profit of his ranſom, or with more cruelty
To make an end of him, I know not which;
I ſaw them take him up into the Boat,
Having diſarm'd him firſt.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: He's loſt, he's loſt!
Juſt Gods grant me revenge upon the Traitor,
And after puniſh me which way you pleaſe for all my ills.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: The hope of that revenge is my excuſe to outlive
My maſter: Think what you are to do.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Thou counſell'ſt well.
O ſir, your help! what is to be done?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I am ſo diſtracted with the accident—

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Lend me your power.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Moſt willingly.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Furniſh ſuch ſhips with all ſpeed poſſible
As are not ſo; ſuch as be ready, clap men aboard
Them ſtrait: For me, were there but one,
By all the Gods, with that I will attempt their reſcue.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Then I muſt go along.

sp.speaker: Age:
sp.l: You!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Yes, I.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Let ſome watch on the ſhore, and ſee if the Admiral
Hoiſe ſail, what courſe he holds.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.l: That ſhall be my imployment; but be aſſured ſir,
Whilſt the wind keeps where it is,
They cannot paſs into the Main.

sp.speaker: K. Age.
sp.l: Continue good heaven, and grant your aid!

div.l: Fortune! thou enemy to wit and induſtry,
How I could curſe thy deity, and this ſame giddy Prince,
That by his new affection gives thee power
To ruine my well-laid plots! But I unjuſtly
Do complain of both: Clorinda's beauty
Is my fate, all my diſaſters take from her
Their being; I will forget her, tear her from my
heart:
But then I overthrow the groundwork
Of my great deſign; no Kingdom,
Nor no happineſs without Clorinda.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: How! no happineſs without Clorinda!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: No happineſs without Clorinda dye,
You know her title to the Crown of Burgonia
Takes place of mine.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: And why then does ſhe live?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: It is a queſtion I may better ask,
I gave you poiſon to diſpatch her.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Rather a Cordial to comfort her,—ſee,
I dare take the reſt.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Hold, dear Selina!

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Dear Selina! Falſe perjur'd man, have I from love
To thee, attempted wickedneſs ſo great,
That horror ſtrikes my ſoul to think upon it;
And after all caſt off like a ſcorn'd property,
Your work perform'd?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: This jealouſie does ſet a greater value on thee:
Come, I will open to thee all my heart;
To make my title ſtrong, I muſt be married
To Clorinda.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: You muſt • !

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Hear me with patience,
I mean in policie it were fit:
But to ſecure your fears, before that paſs,
The Prieſt ſhall ſecretly joyn us together,
Which diſanuls a ſecond marriage.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: If this be real that you ſpeak,
Perform it now betwixt our ſelves,
And call the Gods to witneſs.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Our hearts already have conſented,
What needs there more?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Is it even ſo; I left nothing undone
To the laſt circumſtance, that you deſired;
Gave Clarimant, Clorinda, and the Princeſs
Olinda into your hands. But I perceive
Where your heart's fixt, and I was ſtrangely fool'd,
That ever could believe again.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I like not this, dear Selina,
If you conſider well, you have no ground
For jealouſie from me. The Prince, within whoſe power
We for the preſent are, neglects his former Miſtreſs,
Makes all addreſſes, in my judgment, to Clorinda.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: In this you more confirm me, that you ſtill
Do love Clorinda: ſince jealouſie makes you
Imagine that for which there is no ground;
Or if this Prince like you ſhould prove unfaithful,
Can it be thought Clorinda can be moved
To love again, that had no ſenſe of all
Prince Clarimant hath done or ſuffer'd for he • ſake?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: But ſhe is within his power; and what time
Or force may work! nay, if you will obſerve,
You'll find ſhe ſhews no great averſion to him.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Lend me your eyes, I cannot ſee it elſe:

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: No more; be confident, Selina, I am what I was:

sp.speaker: Sel:
sp.l: Yes, I am confident,
Falſe as the Fiends, too late I find it.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Moſt noble Cleon!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Ha! Cleon?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Lend me your help, to let theſe Ladies know
Nothing but ſervice is intended.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: What mean you ſir? ſhe muſt not know me.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Cleon: Did you not call him Cleon?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: No, Madam.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Sure you did.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Then I miſtook.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Cleander is my name, a ſervant to your beauty
Lady, and this fair Princeſs; whoſe merits
Are ſo great, that by your ſelves conſider'd,
May well aſſure of all obſervance,
Eſpecially from this noble Prince your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs ſir, I believe him every way
So worthy, that I much grieve fortune allotted
Him no other way then force to gain
Poſſeſſion of his Miſtreſs. Come, Madam, be not ſad;
A noble husband makes a large amends
For loſs of friends or country; nor are they loſt
But for the preſent.

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: I know not how (Clorinda) you may value him;
But I muſt tell him plainly, his actions
Speak him baſe and treacherous.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Madam, I ſhall not ſo much grieve to find you
Cruel; ſince this fair Lady not condemns me.

sp.speaker: Clo:
sp.l: You ſhall in nothing, ſir, oblige me more,
Then by your uſing Clarimant with courteſie:
Although your enemy, he is my friend;
A nearer intereſt tho' he moſt deſervingly
Hath ſought, my inclination never could allow him.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I ſhall forget my wounds receiv'd from him;
Neglect all opportunity to take revenge,
If it may be to you a ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Your noble uſage of him whilſt he is your priſoner,
At laſt may turn to your advantage:
Your peace will be the eaſier made with both the Kings;
Nay, without doubt this fair Princeſs
Would eaſily be granted to you
In exchange for him.

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: Me in exchange! firſt I will be wedded to my grave.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Lady, I ſhall not preſs you much:
Your pride and ſcorn darkens your beauty,
Whilſt courteſie ſets off what in this Lady
Needs no foil.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: It is ſo.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I ſee you are a Courtier, ſir, and know how
To oblige thoſe who have power to aſſiſt your wiſhes:
Your favorable opinion of me, engages my
Beſt performance with my deareſt friend
To make her yours; this coyneſs ſhall not laſt,
Leave me to win her for you.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: If you be pleas'd to hold me worthy, I ſhall not
Study to maintain a meaner happineſs.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: He is taken paſt recovery.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Ladies, we dare not longer bar you
The happineſs to enjoy your ſelves.
Diſpoſe of all things freely in this ſhip,
Were it the Empire of the world, moſt
Excellent Clorinda, your power were ſtill the ſame:

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I know you borrow but my name,
The power intended here; and ſo ſhe • uſt
Conceive it.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Sir, let me crave ſome conference with you:

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Command that boy ſtraight from them,
As you reſpect your happineſs:
I'll give you reaſon for it.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: O Madam!

sp.speaker: I.
sp.l: Sir, you muſt go with me.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: What mean you?

sp.speaker: I.
sp.l: The Prince would ſpeak with you.

div.l: Can I yet live, and know Clorinda priſoner,
Subject to all the injuries of power,
And I incapable to ſerve her? I am not ſo;
My hands are free, only my heart is ſlaved
Under misfortune. Were my love ſuch as juſtly
Might ariſe from ſo miraculous a cauſe,
The ardor of my flame would prompt my heart
And hand to find ſome way to ſet her free,
And take revenge upon the treacherous Prince▪
But I do find the cauſe of all this deadneſs:
My thoughts are active, but there wants
Her favorable influence upon me.
O me! what do my fears ſuggeſt!
My eyes and ears, thoſe traitors to my peace,
I will not truſt your baſe intelligence;
You are but the ſervants of my fear, and not my reaſon:
Can injuries or importunity prevail
To make her love this Prince; where love and ſervice
On my part procured but frowns? O yes,
It may be ſo; there is a cruelty in Love,
By which that Deity does magnifie it ſelf:
Reaſon or merit muſt pretend no ſhare
In the free bounties of a heart that Love inclines.
Prince Clarimant!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Why are you ſo amazed?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: What light breaks from that cloud,
And with the ſudden brightneſs dazles my ſenſe!
My happineſs is ſuch, O ſpeak agen,
That by two witneſſes my joys may be confirmed▪

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Why are you thus diſturb'd? you oft have ſeen me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: But never thus, never thus unexpectedly,
When I deſpair'd the happineſs.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Had fortune been ſo envious to deny an opportunity,
As I confeſs this hardly was attain'd,
To give you thanks for the laſt teſtimony of your love;
Yet reaſon, and the eſtimation you do hold of me,
Might well aſſure you I could not but reſent it
Highly.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O heavens!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: You are ſad; does this acknowledgment offend you?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Offend me, dear Clorinda! 'tis ſuch a joy
As juſtly might tranſport me from my ſelf:
But when I do conſider all my merit was but intention
And that I can do nothing real in your ſervice,
The ſenſe of my misfortune ſinks me down low as deſpair.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: The Gods themſelves in what we owe to them,
Do not require above what they inable us
To act: much leſs is due to me,
Who rather am your debtor; which to acquit in part
I chiefly came to clear any ſuſpition
You might have conceived from my kind uſage
Of this traitor Prince; yet know if you believed me
Guilty, it was a crime I can as hardly pardon
As your too much love.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The laſt is ſuch a guilt as every minute multiplies;
And though you cruelly condemn it, ſuch is yet
The riches or my ſoul.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: But if you wiſh, as you profeſs, my happineſs
And ſatisfaction, temper it ſo, that I may pay the like;
The affection of a brother to a ſiſter I will allow you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: In this you do ſo far exceed my hopes or merit,
That it were ingratitude not to acknowledge
A bounty infinitely great: But ſince that
Siſterly affection does not debar you
From conferring a greater happineſs upon ſome other,
A happineſs which I muſt burſt with envy to behold:
Nay, curſe whom you ſo bleſs, you do but raiſe me high,
To throw me down with greater violence.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: To cure this fear, the Gods be witneſs,
No others intereſt ever ſhall exceed Prince Clarimant's.

sp.speaker: Clar:
sp.l: Nor ſhall their happineſs then, by this fair hand.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: But if beyond this you but hope, you injure me
And vertue.—So peace dwell with you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Alas, already you forget your promiſe;
You wiſh peace, and remove it from me,
Would any ſiſter do ſo to a brother?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Yes, to preſerve herſelf and him:
Were we diſcover'd, you were loſt.
The Prince which my unhappy beauty hath ſurprized
Neglects Olinda, and certainly does fix his thoughts
On me: With him, as far as honor would permit,
I have diſſembled, entertain'd his flame
With no diſlike; by which you are preſerv'd as yet▪
And not ill uſed: But this ſtolne viſit
Would to him expreſs more kindneſs
Then he muſt think I have for you—
I hear ſome entring the Cabin—
Heaven! it is the Prince:
Who have we here? Death ſeiſe him,
And throw him overboard.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: O heavens! what art can ſave him?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O for a ſword!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Dare you preſume to ſpeak of love to me,
And do an act ſo baſe? The meer intent,
Were you not rooted here, would cancel all your intereſt.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: My intereſt!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: But if you value my reſpect ſo little,
And your own promiſe for his noble uſage,
Yet wiſdom bids you not forget the advantage
That his life may bring more then his death.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: She tels you true; remember why we did at firſt
Preſerve him to make our peace, ſhould not our plot
Take on Agenor.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Take him away and bind him.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Why ſure he cannot flie: To leap into the ſea,
Were to perform himſelf that which you threaten.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Remove him hence however.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Fortune! that gives this man this power.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I look upon him as a hated Rival, away with him.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Come, I forgive this paſſion, the cauſe
That it proceeds from being love to me,
The error too that you are in is puniſhment enough.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Though I ſuſpect all for diſſembled,
Yet I am pleas'd to hear her; what was my error?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: A groſs miſtake of this ſtolne viſit,
And yet love was my grand errand.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Where's my miſtake then?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Patience, and hear me: You thought Olinda
Once did love you, and you were not miſtaken;
She did ſo till ſhe knew the Prince:
You found her alter'd; and of me miſtaking
The true cauſe, were jealous. Now by the Gods,
If I have truth, ſhe loves the Prince.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: And ſo I fear do you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: By way of gratitude; but for affection,
Heaven witneſs with me I loved another:
Yet where I find diſtruſt and diſreſpect,
Such as you have expreſt, I am no longer bound.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Infinite cunning!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: But to proceed: Finding this Ladies paſſions
Strong to Clarimant, my obligations great,
By way of gratitude, I thought my ſelf obliged
To make him happy in Olinda's love,
And doubt not to effect it, though I muſt bluſh to ſay ſo.
I found ſome arguments beſides that preſt me
To this undertaking; for were their hearts ſo fixt
On other, your peace with both the Kings were quickly made,
And you ſtood free to make a new election:
Yet were all women of my mind,
You ſhould ſtay long enough without a wife, you are ſo paſſionate.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Moſt excellent Clorinda, pardon the raſhneſs of your ſervant,
Who henceforth yields himſelf for ever to be diſpos'd
Of by you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Well, if I find ſo, I never was ungrateful.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: How with a twin'd thred does ſhe ride the Aſs,
And turns him how ſhe pleaſe! but when I conſider,
It is no wonder, ſhe hath a depth of policie
Which all my art could never fathom: True,
Blinded by my love, I could not reach her aims:
But ſtood I free, ſhe wanting the advantage
Of loves power upon me, how poor and ſhallow
Were the arts of all the ſex? But as it is,
Fortune hath given this ſilly Prince
The power to cruſh me into nothing;
Breaks his contract with me touching Clorinda,
Which was the ſoul of all my undertaking.
Is there no way to right my ſelf? yes,
This could revenge my wrongs on him,
But then I periſh in the act, and leave Clorinda
To be enjoy'd by Clarimant: that muſt not be,
No, ere my Rival ſhall ſo happy prove,
I to my hate will ſacrifice my love.

div.head: Act. 5. Scaen. 1.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: SIr, pardon this diſturbance of your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Your preſence rather, faireſt Lady,
May rectifie any diſorder,
Since you are all a harmony of ſweetneſs.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Sir, I perceive your power great with this noble Prince,
And I believe ſo much a friend to him,
That he would hearken to your councel:
If you would join with reaſon, and ſo perſwade him
To ſet Prince Clarimant and the Princeſs at liberty,
I think it were an act would ſhew much friendſhip
To him, and for your ſelf gain what reward
You would deſire from both the Kings.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I have obſerved, moſt beautiful Clorinda,
Such an exceſs of nobleneſs in you,
I ſcarcely dare expreſs what I would undertake
To ſerve you: but then you really
Muſt let me know all your deſires.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: It is Cleon.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Lady, dare you adventure to ſpeak your wiſhes?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I have done ſo.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: That Clarimant and the Princeſs ſhould be
Delivered, I do believe is your deſire:
But is that all? are you pleas'd to be here?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Why ſhould I not? am I not nobly uſed?

sp.speaker: Cle:
sp.l: I know thoſe who are wicked fear not
To break an oath; but ſuch whoſe heart
Is fill'd with vertue, as, I am ſure yours is,
Would not be perjur'd for the world.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: To what tends this?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: That you do ſwear not to diſcover
What I ſhall propoſe touching your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: You need not doubt, if it do ſuit
With what I have expreſt is my deſire.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: My end ſhall be the ſame, their liberty and yours,
Though happily our ways to that may differ.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: My liberty!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Yes, yours the moſt deſired:
Swear, and then hear what I propoſe.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I do, ſo far as vertue binds.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: That tye all men have on you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: If your intents be fair, why will you ask
A ſtronger obligation then?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I dare not ſpeak my thoughts without an oath.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: What can he mean?—I ſwear never to ſpeak
Of that you ſhall propound; nor need I,
Since the Prince does overhear.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Then know, I am not ignorant how you diſſemble
With this treacherous Prince, whom you
And all the world muſt hate.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: This will undo me; I hate the Prince!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Yes, Lady, deadly; yet leſs then I.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: All for your ſake; and for that noble Prince,
If you conſent, this hand, if Clarimant's
Be not more able to effect it,
Shall take revenge, and right our general wrongs.

sp.speaker: Clo:
sp.l: I do complain of none;
If I did, how could this be effected?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: With eaſe; nay more, it is not impoſſible,
The deed done, to eſcape to ſhore in the ſhip-boat,
Into which the Prince and you, the night aſſiſting,
May get before.

div.l: It is impoſſible; you are deceiv'd—
A Guard there!
Seiſe the Villain.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: How? what mean you ſir? All that I ſpoke
Was but to let you ſee how ſhe abuſed you,
And this the plot that Clarimant and ſhe had laid:
You know, upon your life depends my happineſs.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Mine in thy death:
This cunning cannot ſave you, Cleon.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Nor do I wiſh it ſhould,
If you indeed believe me guilty.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Bind him, I will have thee tortur'd limb from limb,
Till thou confeſs all truth.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Let me intreat, ſir, for his life,
However I am by him accuſed.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: For hating me; which I have too much reaſon
To believe is truth.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: How can you think ſo?
Did I not place you to overhear him?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: But knew not what he would deliver.
See Clarimant faſt bound; and (Madam)
My cabin this night ſhall be your chamber.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Perhaps my death-bed; Loſt for ever!
O you juſt Gods! how all my treaſons
Againſt my ſweet and innocent Miſtreſs are return'd
Upon my head! Prince Clarimant, I am thy murdreſs,
To the fair Olinda, by my means betraid:
O horror! what will my torments be for this
Hereafter in the other world? All this
For love of thee falſe Cleon have I done,
Thy curſed brain gave birth to all my plots:
Is this the Crown thou mad'ſt me fondly hope for?
And ſhall I die without revenge? revenge!
My hands faſt bound, there's nothing left that I can
Reach thee with but curſes, fruitleſs curſes.
He ſhall live happy, gain a Kingdom and Clorinda,
By her a Kingdom: why ſhould I pitty her then?
It is ſhe that is the ground of all my miſery,
His love to her makes me thus wretched:
For Clarimant, he may hereafter marry with Olinda,
All but my ſelf may yet be happy:
Muſt I alone die wretched, contemn'd and ſcorn'd?
Why do I longer live, my guilt and miſeries ſo great?
You Gods, or Fiends, remove me from this miſerable
Earth, and let me feel new puniſhments,
If puniſhments there be hereafter,
Theſe they cannot exceed: how ſweet were yet
Revenge! O for revenge, that Cleon's heart
Were in my hand! falſe Cleon's!—no way.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: O deareſt Olinda, what are the miſeries
That we are faln into! Thinking to rid my ſelf
Of a falſe Vilain, I have brought ruine
On us all; no art can help us now.
Oh the hard choice! to marry with this traitor
Prince; or Clarimant muſt die.

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: It were better you conſent to marry with the Prince,
Then that Prince Clarimant ſhould ſuffer;
Let not him die however.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I know your love to Clarimant
Makes you perſwade me thus: and I would quickly yield,
Did not my oath to Clarimant forbid;
But would kill my ſelf ere go to bed.

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs I love the Prince,
Be not offended that I ſay ſo;
It was your perſwaſion firſt: ſince, I have ſeen
Such noble actions, as raiſes him ſo far
Above all other men, that they appear
Not worthy of a thought: And yet my love
And eſtimation of your vertue's ſuch,
I gladly would ſubmit, nay much rejoice
To ſee ſuch merits join'd.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Clarimant, behold your Judge: for know, Clorinda,
This minute you muſt give conſent to marry me,
And go to bed; or elſe immediately his head
Goes off.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: A cruel choice!

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: Baſe man! canſt thou expect to ſcape the hand
Of juſtice, after ſuch cruelty?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: It is not from you, Madam, that I expect
An anſwer: Speak Clorinda, give your ſentence;
For by the Gods there is no way but one of theſe.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: O Clarimant!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Heavens, can you ſuffer
What you have made ſo excellent, to be thus
Miſerable?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Theſe lamentations boot not:
Speak Lady, I can admit of no delay.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: What can I ſay?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: No! ſtrike off his head then.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Oh hold!

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Speak, are you mine?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Say, Clarimant.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Madam, to me death will be eaſe,
Since I have liv'd to ſee you injured thus,
And have not power for to revenge it.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Are you reſolved?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: To ſuffer what thy barbarous nature can inflict.
O help! fire, fire!

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: What cry is that?
Quench, quench the fire.

div.l: O ſir, we are all undone! the fire hath taken
Amongſt the Cabins, paſt all hope of extinguiſhing.
Flie, flie! the ſhip, the cordage is a fire:
For all the water we can bring, it ſtill increaſes.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: What, burn in the ſea! ſlaves, quench the flames.
The Sailors, ſir, deſcend into the Boat:
Make ſure of that, and reach your other ſhips,
The only means of ſafety.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Hell and confuſion!
There's none obey command; but each man looks
To his own ſafety.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O heavens! muſt then Clorinda periſh!

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Make ſure of the Long-boat for me: Some one kill Cleon,
Or rather let him periſh in the flames.
My wounds receiv'd from Clarimant, I Will revenge
My ſelf. [Offers to kill]

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: O ſir, if you have hope in me!

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: It is true; he ſhall not die yet,
But the Gods hereafter ſhall not ſave him,
Though they thus croſt my wiſhes now: Come Lady,
I will take care of you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: We muſt not part.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I mean it not; there may be uſe of her,
Nay for your ſake bring Clarimant along.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: 'Tis for thine own, falſe Prince.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: But look well to him.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You Gods!
Your powerful juſtice in theſe flames is ſhown,
Preſerve Clorinda, and your mercy's known.

div.l: Gramercy fire! the element of water never yet
Afforded me ſo much: this I can ſwim to ſhore
With; yet the wind blows high; but to the
Shoreward I may eſcape; if not, why ſo
Whoever finds my body, ſhall give me thanks.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: O gentle Sailor, untie my hands!

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: A pretty boy; come,—It will not do,
My knife: ſo, canſt ſwim?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Oh no.

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: Then get ſome board or pack: I fear I ſhall be
Drown'd, I am ſo well natur'd on the ſudden.
No uſe of this—

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Juſt heavens!

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: True, Cleon; never ſo manifeſt,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Gentle Selina, unbind my hands:

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I were ingrate elſe, Cleon: you did as much for me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And would do more; any thing; unbind me, Sweet,
I'll ſwim with thee upon my back to ſhore.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: You cannot ſwim, I am ſure you ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: No creature living better; I oft have ſwam two leagues
For pleaſure: O delay not, the fire approaches.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: But will you marry me, and make good all your promiſes?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: By the Gods I will.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Sure you will agen deceive me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Never, by my hopes.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: The only time you ever yet ſpoke truth—
You ſhall not: yet ſtill thy heart is falſe:

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: It is not; quick unbind me, gentle Selina.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Well, for once I'll try what your heart holds.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Bleſt Selina! O cruel! yet ſpare me

div.l: Dear Selina.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Yes, when I ſee your heart, or blood come from it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: O witch, devil▪

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I am to thee ſo: What policie can now defend?
Know to thy greater torment, I ſet the ſhip
On fire, only to be reveng'd on thee,
Not hoping ſuch a happineſs as this,
With theſe to behold thy falſe heart blood.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: O that my eyes could look thee dead!

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I will ſee them cloſed, my deareſt husband,
It is my duty.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Firſt we'll to ſea together.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Since we muſt—

div.stage: Exeunt, fall as into the ſea▪
Enter Prince, Clarimant, Clorinda, Olinda, Sailors.

sp.speaker: 1 Sail.
sp.l: It were beſt to enter further within the wood:
A Boat made after us when we forſook the ſhip:

sp.speaker: 2 Sail.
sp.l: Some Fiſherman, that to avoid the ſtorm,
Put to the ſhore.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Let the winds blow and ſplit, ſince we are
Here: Fire, air, and water have oppos'd my wiſhes;
Kind mother Earth grant what they have denied.
But why ſhould I intreat, that may command
All my deſires? Once more, Clorinda,
I propoſe the choice; ſay, ſhall he die,
Or will you make me happy who loves you
More then he?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Traitor thou lyeſt: He that truly loves Clorinda,
Would give ſome noble teſtimony: Unbinde my hands,
And by my death, as a worthy Rival,
Win her from me: I ask no ſword,
Only the freedom of my hands; but if thy coward heart
Think that too much, take all theſe to aſſiſt:

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: You need not pull death faſter on you
By injurious words; it is ready,
Speak Clorinda, or he dies.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Hold, and give me leave to ſpeak a few ſad words.
Dear Clarimant, I know to ſave your life,
And yield my ſelf anothers, were ſuch a choice
You never could allow, ſince to the miſerable
Life is a burden: Could my death
Make you happy, the Gods be witneſs
I would lay it down with joy,
Our fates I find are one; the merit of your love
And ſufferings for my ſake is ſuch,
That I ſhould hold my ſelf ingrate,
Did I not grant you any thing
That I might think might comfort you in death.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: But ſhall I dare to ſpeak wy wiſhes?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: More then dare; I do enjoin it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: There is a happineſs would make my death
My triumph.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I underſtand you. Here! alas that I ſhould give
My hand to Clarimant, and he not able
To receive it 1 Our hearts may yet be join'd
For ever, and only by theſe miſeries
They could have been.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Is this the fruit of my delay.
To hear my Rival courted?

div.stage: Offers to kill Clar. Clo. ſteps between, and O •• . hinders it.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Know tyrant, 'tis the ſame,
One ſtroke diſpatches both.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Strike here then, vilain.

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: Devil, doſt thou believe there are no Gods?

sp.speaker: Age:
sp.l: Clindor, this way I ſaw them enter.

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: I am out of breath, ſir.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Ha, who are theſe?

sp.speaker: Clind.
sp.l: See ſir, the traitor Prince.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Unbind me, dear Clorinda.

div.stage: (Agenor and Clindor fight with the Prince, then drive off the Sailors and follow them: Clar. kills the Prince. Then)

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O deareſt brother, how is it with you?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Well, Clarimant, never ſo well.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: By all that's good, you never in my eye Lookt half ſo lovely as now: yet till this day
I never could have ſaid I lov'd another better
Then your Majeſty.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: If it be Clarimant, my joys are then compleat.

sp.speaker: Olind.
sp.l: It is he, ſir; who could elſe deſerve it?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: How favourable are the Gods unto the vertuous!
How juſt to wicked men! How glad will my Auſtela be
Of this, who with the King will ſtraight be here?
They from the ſhore beheld your ſhip, when it
Took fire, ſaw you put off from it,
And watcht your landing certainly.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Know you what Bark it was
That follow'd us at ſea?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: I was in that, and Clindor,
Some twenty with me to watch the ſhip,
Till other Veſſels were prepared:
So ſwift ſhe was of ſail, that all the Fleet
Could not have hurt us.—See, the King!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: What happineſs? all ſafe?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Welcom again, my deareſt.

sp.speaker: Age:
sp.l: Let's loſe no time; delay were now ingratitude:
See, a Temple cloſe by prompts us
To the performance of two duties:
The burial of this unhappy Prince;
But chiefly to render thanks unto the Gods.
Deliverance ſo great, alacrity commands
In giving thanks: that done, we'll join your hands.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: It were folly now to deny the ceremonial,
The real part already paſt.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O dear Clorinda!
'Twere vain to think words could my joys expreſs,
Rais'd from deſpair to ſuch a happineſs.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: FIrſt, Ladies, unto you I am addreſt;
As thoſe who judge of Lovers actions beſt:
If Clarimant your ſuffrages hath gain'd,
Our Author hath his chiefeſt end obtain'd:
Now Sirs to you—
Sure here's no Lover will Clorinda blame
For gratitude, ſince you muſt hope the ſame:
Perhaps you rather think ſhe was too nice,
That ſuch a flame no ſooner thaw'd her ice:
Our Author hopes ſhe did but her juſt part;
He nobly woo'd, ſhe timely gave her heart:
To both the ſexes we prefer this ſute;
Ere you give ſentence, with your ſelves diſpute:
If then condemn'd, to whom ſhould we appeal,
But to that Prince that pardons faults of zeal?
If then condemn'd, 'twere pride to make appeal,
Yet there remains a pardon in our zeal:
